Description: Cattle that originates from Jutland.
Description Of Specific Uses: In 2003, Almost all cattle of the Jutland Cattle are therefore used as suckler cows although the breed has a past as a dairy breed.
Additional information: In 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed. 2012: Information based on number of living animals per 22nd of November. 2013: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of October. 2014: Information based on number of living animals per 18th of February. 2015: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of March. 2016: Information based on number of living animals per 3rd of February.
Efabis cultural role comment: indigenous cattle from Jutland
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is very robust and hardy.
Color comments: multi coloured: mainly black and white, also grey and white
Description of origin: Jutland Cattle derive from indigenous breed cattle in Jutland. In 1881 the first herd-book was published. It distinguished between animals of dairy type and animals of beef type. During the first part of the 20th century the breed was selected for milk production and it was called Black and White Dairy Breed from Jutland. In 1950 this breed was joined with black and white cattle from Holland and Germany to form the SDM breed. A few breeders did however continue to breed the original Danish type. In the 1980s it was almost extinct, when a programme to save this old Danish breed was launched.

Description: Conservation programme for part of the Danish Shorthorn cattle, a line of dairy Shorthorn, referred to as "Lyngestammen".
Additional information: Common for Shorthorn cattle is a high growth rate and high-quality meat with a good marbeling. The milk yield is relatively high with a low lipid content in the milk. The cattle is long-lived and well-tempered. Calvings are uncomplicated and the cows are good parents. Very good health.  The Danish Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fishery supports breeders of Dansk Korthorn. All 7 breeders received support in 2005. The population data are base on 100% pure-bred individuals. In addition, a number of individuals are between 75% and almost 100% pure-bred.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Uncomplicated calvings, good parenting by cows.
Special characteristic of product: QUite low lipid content of milk. High quality meat with good marbeling.
Color comments: multi coloured: red and white or roan
Horn shape size and comments: Pale horsn arched downwards.
Description of origin: Originates from Dairy Shorthorn imported from United Kingdom. The Korthorn had its great period in from 1900 to 1950 after which the breed did not meet increased production demands. Today, breeding has separated it into the old dairy (dual-purpose) line and the more modern Beefshorthorn. The old line was never crossed with Beefshorthorn.
Import: First imported form the UK in 1848

Color comments: uni coloured: brown
Description of origin: continually imported from France; mainly as sire breed in beef x dairy cross-breeding
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was measured on a performance test station for bulls at 7-13 months of age in 1997.

Additional information: 1997: Information based on number of females served by AI. 2012: Information based on number of living animals per 22nd of November. 2013: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of October. 2014: Information based on number of living animals per 18th of February. 2015: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of March. 2016: Information based on number of living animals per 3rd of February.
Special characteristic of product: The milk of this breed contains high protein.
Color comments: uni coloured: red or brown with dark muzzle and hooves
Description of origin: originated from local cattle on the islands Fuen and Sealand and cattle from Angel and Ballum (Schleswig)
Import: in 1970 from Brown Swiss (USA), Red Holstein (Canada), Swedish Red-and-White (Sweden)
Managment conditions performance measure: Milk parameters are the average yield of the 1.lactation of all milk recorded cows in 305 days. Meat parameters have been mesaured on young bulls on performance test stations.
Comments managment conditions: The Danish Red is used in intensive dairy production systems. The majority of cows is housed in tie barn systems during winters. Heifers are reared in loose holding systems and summer grazing. Male calves are used for production of bullocs, in intensive production systems, and slaughtered at approximately 11 month of age, at a liveweight of approximately 440 kgs.

Description: Red coloured Danish breed of milking cattle as bred until year 1970.
Other name: Danish Red Cattle, Red Danish Dairy Cattle
Description Of Specific Uses: The breed is a dairy breed with relative high production capacity, and high fat- and protein content in the milk. Male calves are traditionally used for bullock production.
Additional information: Conservation Programme: The Danish Ministry of Environment and Food supports breeders of RDM-1970. 27 breeders received support in 2005. The population data include the RDM-1930 line of RDM. There are 3 breeding males and 75 breeding female sin this line. They are 7 breeders attending this line - they have approx. 14 animals each.
Efabis cultural role comment: > 100 Years of pure breeding with a national danish breed
Special characteristic of product: The fat and protein content of the milk is high. The high content of capaprotein makes the milk suitable for cheese production.
Color comments: uni coloured: red with dark muzzle and hooves
Horn shape size and comments: Mid-sized, arched horns that point upwards or forwards. The horns may be white or grey-yellow, often with black tips.
Description of origin: In the 1840s, original cattle on the Eastern Danish islands were crossed with red cattle from the Southern part of Denmark. Three groups of cattle were used: Angler Cattle, Northern Slesviger Cattle and Ballum Cattle. The resulting cattle was the foundation for the Red Danish Dairy Cattle, RDM, officially formed in 1878. The RDM was most popular in the 1950s but it has decreased a lot since then. From the late 1970s the breed association introduced breeding material from other breeds, e.g. Brown-Swiss, Red Holstein and Swedish Red, into the RDM. Only a small fraction of the breeders continued pure-breeding after this, and they formed "RDM-1970". Subsequently, a small group of breeders formed the "RDM-1930" - a slightly different line. Both lines represent the original Red Danish Dairy Cattle.

Additional information: 1997: Information based on number of females served by AI in 1997. 2012: Information based on number of living animals per 22nd of November. 2013: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of October. 2014: Information based on number of living animals per 18th of February. 2015: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of March. 2016: Information based on number of living animals per 3rd of February.
Color comments: multi coloured: black, white
Description of origin: A herd book for the local black and white cattle of Jutland (The Jutland cattle) was first established in 1881. In 1949 this breed was pooled with an increasing population of Dutch and German black and white cattle, and this new synthetic breed was called SDM or Sortbroget dansk Malkerace. Since 1965 imports of semen from other black and white populations, mainly from USA and Canada, but lately also from Holland and France, has taken place. To date (1998) the Danish Friesian is a strain of the international HF-breed, with only 25% of its genes originating from the original Danish dual purpose breed from 1965 (SDM-1965).
Import: since 1965 from Holstein-Friesian from USA, Canada, The Netherlands, Germany and France
Managment conditions performance measure: Intensive dairy production systems. The majority of cows is housed in tie barns during winter. Heifers are reared in loose holdings, and summer grazing. Male calves are used for production of bullocs in intensive production indoor systems, and slaughtered at approximately 11 months of age at a liveweight of approximately 440 kg.

Description: Black and white coloured Danish breed of milking cattle as bred before year 1965.
Other name: SDM, Dansk Holstein, Danish Holstein, Danish Black and White Cattle
Additional information: 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed.
Efabis cultural role comment: It represents the original dual-purpose-friesian
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white
Description of origin: When the Danish Friesian Breed organisation opened the herd-book to allow inclusion of Holstein Friesian, semen of bulls of the European type of Friesian cattle was stored. On basis of this storage it has been possible to breed a line of Friesians without HF genes. In order to distinguish this line the year (1965) has been added to the breed name abbreviation.

Description Of Specific Uses: Used by hobby breeders preferring the natural brooding of chickens. Breeders concerned with its socio-cultural importance and conservation.
Additional information comments: The Danish Country Chicken is also found in a black colour variety and a variety called the Lutte Chicken. The Lutte Chicken has very short legs, its name referring to its walk. It is thought to be even older than the Danish Country Chicken and is slightly heavier.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to temperate climates.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Resistance to infectious diseases and parasites.
Specific reproductive characteristic: A good layer, particularly at mild temperatures. Good vitality and robust, fast-growing chickens. The hen is a good sitter and a good chicken shepherd.
Other special qualities: This breed is known for longevity. Relatively low feed consumption but actively fouraging.
Description of origin: The breed was developed in Denmark but dates back more than 2000 years. It is thought to descend from a wild Asian jungle fowl, Gallus bankiva. It was brought to Denmark by Germanic tribes and was the only breed kept in the country until the early 1800s. A formal selection program was initiated in 1879.
Location within country: 30-40 serious breeders (ca. 50 animals per breeder) organized in ”Danmarks Fjerkræavlerforening for Raceavl” (Danish Poultry Breeders). Distributed throughout the country.

Description: Population data for 2017 does not include mixed breeds
Color comments: Some has a white spot on the stomach, the tale and the paws.
Efabis main colour: Golden red, yellow with black face or black.
Description of origin: The breed is a reconstruction of the Old Danish Dog from the mid 16th century, and was in mid 19th century registered under the name Broholmeren. Due to lack of interest, the last registrered dog died in 1956. However, in 1974 the breed was re-created from animals, that had the same appearance as the old breed.

Efabis main colour: Mostly white with brown markings and stains.

Additional information: Grows fast and has high meat production. Meat juicy and tasty.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for a high egg yield and good broodiness of the hens.
Special characteristic of product: Eggs, meat.
Other special qualities: These are very hardy animals.
Color comments: Egg shells blue.green.
Efabis main colour: Black with white chest. Red-yellow legs with dark spots.
Description of origin: Was established in Denmark based on ducks from countries bordering the Baltic Sea.
Location within country: Kept by a few poultry breeders and people interested in conserving old Danish breeds.

Description Of Specific Uses: Before the invention of paper, goat skin was used for parchment production. Presently, the goat is kept for niche production of milk, and to a lesser degree, meat.
Additional information: The Danish Indigenous Goat belongs to the common Northern European and Scandinavian type of goat. The breeding goal is to maintain the Danish Indigenous Goat as a typical representative of the old Danish goat breed - as it has developed through an altered natural environment and selection. The goat thrives in herds, and males and young animals are particularly well-suited for landscape management.
Adaptability to specific environment: Well-adapted to the Danish weather conditions and only kept in stables November-April.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Good health
Specific reproductive characteristic: Normally 2 kids. Rarely complications during parturition. Kids vigorous and fast-growing.
Special characteristic of product: Milk quality studies based on a single herd of goats has indicated that the protein composition if the milk is unique to this breed and makes the milk particularly suitable for cheese production.
Color comments: The goats in the photographs are wildtype.
Efabis main colour: There are seven different colour varieties: wildtype, black wildtype, Harz-coloured, black, black-and-white, white and blue. The hair is short to longish with a coat consisting of two layers: guard hair and wool hair which is shed during summer.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are arched backwards with a slight outward twist.  Usually, the goat has horns, but culled animals are not uncommon.
Description of origin: The earliest findings of goat bones in Denmark date back to 3400 B.C. In medieval times, several manors kept large herds of goats. Later, it became a cheap alternative to dairy cows.
Year of origin: In late 18th and early 19th century, the Danish Indigenous Goat was bred for higher milk yield.
Import: A limited crossbreeding to dairy goats from Norway, Saanen goats from Switzerland and Harz goats from Germany.
Location within country: All of Denmark with most herds in Jutland and on Sealand and with a few herds on Funen and smaller islands.

Additional information: Very robust, both as goslings and adults. Actively fouraging and may therefore find its own feed during large parts of the year.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The females are known for broodiness.
Special characteristic of product: The meat is fine but the goose may be a bit large compared to what consumers want.
Other special qualities: These are very hardy animals.
Efabis main colour: There are two colour varieties: (1) grey and (2) speckled-grey. (1) is mouse-coloured with darker areas on wings, light abdomen and hind. (2) is white with a greay head, grey areas on wings and sides.
Description of origin: Breed started in Denmark based on geese imported from countries bordering the Baltic Sea. The goose is closely related to the Pomeranian goose, the Swedish goose and other country breed geese in the region.

Description: Conservation programme for pure bred.
Description Of Specific Uses: The Jutland horse is used as a draught horse for e.g. a couple of brewer's drays from the Carlsberg Brewery.
Additional information: In 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed. 2005: souce of data: National office for horse breeds. 2005: souce of data: National office for horse breeds
Efabis cultural role comment: dominant horse in danish agriculture for almost a century
Color comments: uni coloured: usually chestnut, sometimes sorrel (brownish-orange) or roan often with white markings on face and legs
Description of origin: native
Import: since 1950, < 5% from Shire (United Kingdom), Suffolk (United Kingdom)

Description: The breed organization accepts few controlled cross-breedings each year to reduce the risk of inbreeding. Conservation programme for pure bred.
Additional information:
2005: source of data: National office for horse breeds; The breed organization accept cross-breeding with stallions of other breeds. A group of breeders are trying to keep a pure-bred line. A conservation programme was initiated in 1997, were financial support is granted to breeders of males with at least 15/16 blood from original Frederiksborg horses.
In 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed.
Efabis cultural role comment: considered as the national danish horse
Other special qualities: Energetic, good drive. Strong, good staying power.
Efabis main colour: All colours are acceptable. Most horses are chestnut.
Description of origin: Native Danish country breed derived from Andalusian and Neapolitanian horses, founded at the Royal National Stud in the late 1600s.
Location within country: country-wide, but mainly on Zealand and Funen

Description: Conservation programme for pure bred.
Description Of Specific Uses: The Knabstrupper is an all-round horse used for various purposes. It is found in a variety of sizes, and children may grow up with the good-tempered, manageable Knabstrupper.
Additional information: The Knabstrupper horse is good-tempered, willing to work and has good staying power.  There are two Knabstrupper associations in Denmark: (1) Knabstrupperforeningen for Danmark (The Knabstrupper Association of Denmark): Some breeders in this association allow crossing with more than ten other horse breeds. Other breeders run the"Pure Breeding Programme" aiming to conserve the Knabstrupper breed by certifying each individual with more than 50% Knabstrupper descendancy with a proportion of Knabstrupper ancestors in its pedigree. Presently, the requirement is 6/8 in the 3rd remove. The stringency of this requirement will increase until 2025, aiming for 15/16 purity of all individuals. Both males and females are used in the programme. Males presented in the programme are only allowed up to ten matings if their morphological assessment is not satisfying. This procedure was chosen to ensure the conservation of a number of lines, even if not all the males are accepted into the Pure Breeding Programme. (2) International Knabstrupper Raceforening (International Knabstrupper Breeders Association): Aim to conserve the Knabstrupper breed by avoiding breeding material from any other breeds. Cooperate with Knabstrupper breeders in other countries.
Efabis genetic features: There are two Knabstrupper associations in Denmark and they have different breeding goals (see "Additional information"). If one considers individuals complying with the requirements of the "Pure Breeding Programme", the number of males used in breeding is 12, and the number of females is 80. This sums up to 92 individuals, instead of the 187 recorded under Population Data.
Efabis main colour: Knabstrupper complexion or speckled (see photos). All colours, except piebald and palomino.
Description of origin: The breed originates from a mare brought to Denmark by Spanish soldiers in the early 1800s and Danish Frederiksborger horses. The Spanish mare was used for breeding at the Knabstrup mansion.
Import: Knabstrupper horses have been exported, particulary in the 1970s and 1980s, and some of the progeny of these horses is imported by Danish breeders.

Additional information:
1993: Almost 100% of pigs produced in Denmark have a Landrace or Yorkshire mother. Landrace is utilized as a partner in cross-breeding schemes with Yorkshire.
In 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for high litter sizes.
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Description of origin: indigenous breed Danish land pig

Other name: Danish Black Spotted, Danish White and Black, Danish Black Pied
Additional information: 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: black, white
Description of origin: indigenous breed local breed

Description Of Specific Uses: Since this is the only Danish rabbit breed, it is of cultural and historical importance to conserve it.
Efabis cultural role comment: Hvid Dansk Landkanin is the only rabbit breed that originates in Denmark, and therefore it plays a cultural/historical role.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Females have good parenting qualities
Other special qualities: Young rabbits have a high growh rate relative to feed intake
Color comments: Albino
Description of origin: Ca. 1900, the white variety of "Danish rabbit" and Belgian Giant were crossed by the head of Copenhagen Zoo, Julius Schiøtt, to produce a large albino rabbit - Hvid Dansk Landkanin. This breed was displayed for the first time at a show in Tivoli, Copenhagen in 1908. In the 1950s and 1960s, the breed was very popular, and thousands of animals were exported for breeding in England, Germany, Hungary and Switzerland.

Additional information: 2003, The Genetic Resources Committee has made a big effort to stop the decrease in number of animals of old national breeds. The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed.
Efabis cultural role comment: development of local textil industries
Color comments: uni coloured: white with grey head
Description of origin: composite of Danish Heath and Merino (18th century) with some Leicester Longwool and Oxford Down input (1900)

Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is reportedly weather resistant and well adapted to marsh lands.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for high fertility.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: very common in the marsh land
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Description of origin: imported from Germany and United Kingdom

Color comments: uni coloured: varies from black through red and brick to yellow
Description of origin: variety of Tropical Dairy Criollo

This breed was created in the cattle ranch of the Central Romana Corporation, through crossbreeding and selection for more than 50 years. Its genetic base makes reference to the Criollo cattle that originally came from Spain starting from 1492. This breed was crossed with varieties of Zebu, mainly the Guzerat and Missouri. These were bulls of red colour, presumably of African origin that gave red offspring. The Nelore breed coming from Louisiana and kept by cattle breeders in the eastern region of the country were also used as sire line.

Adaptability to specific environment: The Cheurfa is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Cheurfa is able to valorize forages and coarse food and is well adapted to restricted food resources. It is also resistant to disease, parasites and insects.
Color comments: The Cheurfa presents a whitish color with a white muzzle and dark eyelids.
Horn shape size and comments: The Cheurfa has long horns curving upwards.
Description of origin: The Cheurfa belongs to the Atlas Brown branch. The distribution area of the Atlas Brown covers all of North Africa and whose ancestor would be the Bos primigenius mauritanicus.
Location within country: The Cheurfa lives on the edge of forests and in the lakeside and coastal areas of El-Tarf and Annaba, where the majority of the population is located. It is also present in the regions of Guelma, Skikda, Jijel and Sétif.
Feeding of adults: agro-industrial by-products, concentrate, farm-household by-products, fodder, grazing, uncontrolled feeding

Adaptability to specific environment: The Chélifienne is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Chélifienne is able to valorize forages and coarse food and is well adapted to restricted food resources. It is also resistant to disease, parasites and insects.
Color comments: The Chélifienne presents a fawn coat color with a white muzzle and dark eyelids.
Horn shape size and comments: The Chélifienne has horns curved generally forward.
Description of origin: The Chélifienne belongs to the Atlas Brown branch. The distribution area of the Atlas Brown covers all of North Africa and whose ancestor would be the Bos primigenius mauritanicus.
Location within country: The Chélifienne lives in the mountainous areas of Chlef, it is often found in the mountains of Dahra.
Feeding of adults: agro-industrial by-products, concentrate, farm-household by-products, fodder, grazing, uncontrolled feeding

Adaptability to specific environment: The Guelmoise is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Guelmoise is able to valorize forages and coarse food and is well adapted to restricted food resources. It is also resistant to disease, parasites and insects.
Color comments: The coat color of the Guelmoise varies between light and dark gray with a lighter part on the flank and back.  It has a white muzzle and a black eyelids.
Horn shape size and comments: The Guelmoise has horns curved generally forward and sometimes upwards.
Description of origin: The Guelmoise belongs to the Atlas Brown branch. The distribution area of the Atlas Brown covers all of North Africa and whose ancestor would be the Bos primigenius mauritanicus.
Location within country: The Guelmoise lives in the forest and mountainous areas in the regions of Guelma, El Tarf and Jijel.
Feeding of adults: agro-industrial by-products, concentrate, farm-household by-products, fodder, grazing, uncontrolled feeding

Adaptability to specific environment: The Sétifienne is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Sétifienne is able to valorize forages and coarse food and is well adapted to restricted food resources. It is also resistant to disease, parasites and insects.
Color comments: The Sétifienne presents a blackish coat with a brown line on the back that characterizes this population. The muzzle is white and the eyelids are black.
Horn shape size and comments: The Sétifienne has curving horns forward or upwards.
Description of origin: The Sétifienne belongs to the Atlas Brown branch. The distribution area of the Atlas Brown covers all of North Africa and whose ancestor would be the Bos primigenius mauritanicus.
Location within country: The Sétifienne lives in the mountainous areas of the Sétif region, it would also be present in Jijel.
Feeding of adults: agro-industrial by-products, concentrate, farm-household by-products, fodder, grazing, uncontrolled feeding

Color comments: comment: dark coloured coat
Description of origin: Crosbreed between Chaâmbi breed and l'Ouled Sidi Echikh.

Color comments: comment: light coloured or spotted
Description of origin: Race des Touareg du Nord (fr.)

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is highly susceptible to trypanosomiasis and can be reared only in areas not affected by this disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The following data are given: Age at first insemination from 6 to 8 months; Bodyweight: 22/23 kg; Fertility: 90%; Prolificity: 100-120%; Fecundity: 110%
Other special qualities: These are very hardy animals which can remain two days without drinking.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey, brown, white, blond
Description of origin: variety of Sahelian: There are two sub-types of Arabia, a sedentary and a transhumant type. The sedentary type has longer hair (14-21 cm) compared to the transhumant type (10-17 cm). Predominant colours of the sedentary type are black, pied black and brown.
Additional performance parameters: - slaughter weight kg 42 (f) and kg 55 (m);

Color comments: uni coloured: brown multi coloured: black, brown
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were measured on goats kept under a extensive systems.

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is highly susceptible to trypanosomiasis and can be reared only in areas not affected by this disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The following data are given for this breed: Prolificacy: 125%; Fecundity: 105%: Fertility 100%.
Other special qualities: These are very hardy animals which can remain two days without drinking.
Color comments: comment: various colours
Description of origin: variety of Sahelian
Location within country: high plateaux and in northern regions of Algeria.
Comments managment conditions: The animals are given some supplements in times of feed shortage.

Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed produces young twice a year. The following data were given: Prolificacy: 160-200%; Fecundity: 140%.
Color comments: uni coloured: predominantly chamois (fawn), also black, brown, white
Description of origin: The breed originated in Metlili, Ghardaia region.
Additional performance parameters: - slaughter weight kg 35 (f) and kg 60 (m)

Other name: Bariolee du Sahel, Fulani, Touareg, West African Longlegged, Sahel
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is highly susceptible to trypanosomiasis and can be reared only in areas not affected by this disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The following data are given for this breed: Prolificacy: 125%; Fecundity: 105%: Fertility 100%.
Other special qualities: These are very hardy animals which can remain two days without drinking.
Color comments: comment: various colours
Location within country: high plateaux and in northern regions of Algeria
Comments managment conditions: The animals are given some supplements in times of feed shortage.

Adaptability to specific environment: These animals do not require much attention and can survive under harsh conditions.
Other special qualities: The breed is bigger and stronger than Arab horses with high hind quarters and feet especially adapted for speed. This breed has been introduced into horse shows since 1975. The breed has been used in wars, for cultural festivals and for work.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Description of origin: This breed is the result of a cross between Arab and Barb horses and is the best known horse breed in Algeria.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, fed on total grazing with barley and oat concentrates.
Comments managment conditions: These animals are fed on total grazing and barley and oats concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: This breed is in heat seasonally from Feburary to June, duration of heat is 7 days with average fecundity of 80-95%.

Other special qualities: This breed is an excellent saddle horse, characterised by its endurance and rusticity.
Color comments: uni coloured: chestnut, grey, bay
Location within country: originated in the steppe zones of Tebessa, M'sila, Barika, Tiaret, Saida, Boussaada and Setif
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for the whole year and fed on a diet rich in sugar, barley, hay, oat husks and straw.
Additional performance parameters:
- fecundity 80-95%;
- breeding season from February to June;

Other name: Constantinois, Moutons de l'Oued Souf, Tunisien, Barbary, Mouton à queue grasse
Additional information: This breed is related to the Tunisian Barbarine but is distinguished by a fat half-tail, less prominent than that of the Tunisian Barbarine
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to live under desert conditions (extreme heat) and feeds on dune grass. His big hooves make him an excellent walker in the dunes of Souf (El Oued) in particular. They are considered irreplaceable in their environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: These sheep fatten quickly and can tolerate salty water.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed has very good prolificacy qualities.
Other special qualities: These animals are suitable for a transhumant or nomadic lifestyle.
Color comments: The body of the barbarine is white except the head and legs which may be brown or black.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are developed in the male, absent in the female.
Description of origin: This breed is thought to be of Asian origin.
Location within country: Its area of extension covers the east of the country, from Souf to the Constantine trays to the Tunisian border.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were measured on animals kept under stationary conditions and fed on total grazing in springtime. They may have been supplemented with 300g of barley per day.

Additional information: The Berbère sheep is a direct descendant of the Africana sheep or more exactly of the African branch. This quaternary sheep which was for a very long time the only North African sheep, going from Morocco to Tunisia, via the chain of the Telien Atlas in Algeria.
Adaptability to specific environment: The Berbère breed is traditionally bred in cold valleys and well-watered wooded mountains. It can survive on marginal lands.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Berbère is a very hardy animal, resistant to cold and humidity.
Other special qualities: The breed is a very poor milk producer and its performance in general is not great except that it can survive on marginal land and represents ancient stock. The animals survive quite well on scrub.
Color comments: The Berbère sheep is characterized by a shiny white wicking wool, called "Azoulaï" in the Berber language. There are a few specimens black speckled.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are present in both sexes, they are small and spiral.
Description of origin: The Berbère sheep constitutes the oldest ovine population of North Africa, probably resulting from interbreedings with the wild moufflon.
Location within country: Its area of extension covers the whole mountains of the Telien Atlas from Moroccan to the Tunisian borders.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from sheep kept under stationary conditions and fed on total grazing and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters:
- fecundity 90%;
- prolificity 110%;

Adaptability to specific environment: This breed survives well under Sahelian conditions.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for prolificacy. The animals breed all year round.
Other special qualities: These are rustic animals.
Color comments:
uni coloured: black, brown, white
multi coloured: black and white pied
Description of origin: The historical origin of the D'man breed is not well known, it has existed in the palm groves of the pre-Saharan regions of southern Morocco for a very long time.
Location within country: The D'man exists in the oases of southwest Algeria: Gourara, Touat, Tidikelt and goes as far as el Golea in the east and extends into the desert areas south of Bechar.
Additional performance parameters: - prolificacy 185-200%;

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its resistance to cold, wind and droughts.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breeding season lasts from spring to autumn (300 days).
Special characteristic of product: This is a very good meat breed.
Other special qualities: The animals survive on Halfa-grass (Stipa tenacissima) used on dunes to prevent erosion.
Color comments: multi coloured: white with dark mahogany head and legs
Description of origin: originated in the East of Morocco.
Location within country: area between Chotte Ech-Chergui in the East, the Saharian Atlas in the South-east, Morocco in the West and the mountains of Tlemcen and Saida in the North.
Comments managment conditions: 90% of the animals kept by nomads do not receive any treatment.
Additional performance parameters:
- fecundidy 90%;
- prolificity 110-120%;

Adaptability to specific environment: These animals are well adapted to live in the arid zones.
Special characteristic of product: This is an excellent meat breed and the daily gain is quite good.
Other special qualities: The animals are adapted to long walks.
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Location within country: eastern Algeria stretching across to Wadi Touil on the Tunisian border
Comments managment conditions: 90% of the animals kept by nomads are fed on total grazing only, those kept under stationary conditions have their diets supplemented with straw.
Additional performance parameters:
- fecundity 95%;
- prolificity 110%;

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to extreme cold, dryness, mountainess conditions and poor pastures.
Color comments: multi coloured: red or brownish head, body uni coloured bay-fawn
Location within country: extends from L'oued Touil in the east to Chott Chergui in the west
Comments managment conditions: The breed is fed on concentrates in times of lack of grazing.
Additional performance parameters:
- fecundity 95%;
- prolificity 110%;

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local Saharan climate.
Other special qualities: These animals can walk long distances.
Color comments:
uni coloured: white, fawn
multi coloured: pied
Description of origin: Sahel type originated in Mali.
Comments managment conditions: The animals are fed with barley, dry dates and dry fodder after lambing.
Additional performance parameters:
- fertility (first lambing) 98% (other) 100%;
- after first lambing sheep give birth twice per year

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the steppe and semi-steppe zones.
Special characteristic of product: This is a productive breed with excellent meat quality as the fat is regularly dispersed between the muscle and under the skin which gives a sort of marbling effect.
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Description of origin: Descended from Algerian Arab (Ouled Djellal) with some Merino (France) input.
Location within country: Originated in Tadmit in the Wilaya de Djelfa, between Messad and Djelfa, then spread into the north as far as Ksar el Boukhari
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions and fed on total grazing and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters:
- fertility 91%;
- prolificity 110%;

Description: Commonly called by breeders "Tazegzawt" = blue color in the Tamazight language, due to the presence of pigmentation at the level of the head of shiny bluish black color. Typical sheep from the mountains and the Soummam valley, perfectly adapted to the natural conditions of the region.
Location within country: The area of expansion of this breed mainly concerns two wilayas of northern Algeria (Béjaia and Tizi Ouzou), but the large concentration of numbers is observed in the area of Akbou (Béjaia)

Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptation to natural pasture at 3 500 m asl. is reported for this breed.
Description of origin: Imported from Peru
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were measured in the National Park Cotopaxi unter the responsibility of INEFAN.

Horn shape size and comments: short coiled horns
Description of origin: Bubalus bubalis, subspecies bubalis
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was measured under transhumant conditions with total grazing, and was recorded by the Ministry of Agriculture.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to highland conditions in altitudes above 3 500 m asl.

Description of origin: originates from a local breed and importations (Pekin)

Specific reproductive characteristic: Kids are born all year round.
Color comments:
uni coloured: usually black, light brown, red
multi coloured: pied
Description of origin: first introduced in 1813 (1 male, 3 females)
Location within country: Galapagos Islands, 9 islands of the archipelago Sur de Isabela, Santa Cruz, San Salvador, San Cristobal, Floreana, Marchena, Pinta, Espanola and Baltra

Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptation to natural pasture at 3 500 m asl. is reported for this breed.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance has been measured in the National Park Cotopaxi unter the responsibility of INEFAN.

Description of origin: composite of local breed, crosses and San Nicholas

Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptation to natural pasture at 4 000 m asl. is reported for this breed.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were measured in the National Park Chiamorazo unter the responsibility of INEFAN.

Horn shape size and comments: long curved horns
Description of origin: variety of Baladi
Location within country: north and central areas of the Delta, Lower Egypt (northern Egypt) and mid Egypt

(1983) M.Sc. Thesis Khafr El-Sheikh, Tanta University, Egypt.

- number of lactations/life 7-8;

Color comments: uni coloured: dark grey
Horn shape size and comments: long curved horns

Location within country: southern and central parts of the Delta

Other name: Domiati, Domiatti, Domyati, Dumiati, Dumyati, Domiatta
Description of origin: variety of Egyptian cattle
Location within country: mainly in the north-eastern part of the Nile Delta

Abs. 54 276. Galal et al (1977) J. Agri. Sci. Cambridge. 89 113-117 Mostageer et al (1987) Zeit. Tierz. Zuch. Biologie 104, 383-390.

Description of origin: variety of Egyptian with some Zebu blood
Location within country: central and southern parts of Upper Egypt (southern Egypt)
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey El-Itriby et al (1963) Proc. 2nd Animal Prod. Conf., Cairo, Egypt pp 475-483.

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to leukosis and spiroketosis.
Specific reproductive characteristic: A fertility of more than 95% is reported for these birds.
Description of origin: originated in the northern region and the Delta of Egypt

Specific reproductive characteristic: A fertility of more than 95% is reported for these birds. Furthermore, they are known as good layers.
Special characteristic of product: The animals of this breed are also used as table birds.
Color comments:
multi coloured: two colour varieties exist:1) females pinkish with white breast feathers and 2) colombian pattern, with black markings on neck, wing and tail
comment: day old chicks are yellow to creamy showing various degrees of black markings/stripes on the neck
Description of origin: locally adapted breed

Other special qualities: Day old chicks: chick sexing by the white head patch. The head patch is narrow in the female and large spread in the male.
Color comments: comment: adult birds have blue plumage due to the presence of white and black, neck feathers are silvery white, red ear lobes, day old chick have greyish brown stripes
Description of origin: This crossing between Fayoum and Barred Plymouth Rock has been developed by the Dokki Poultry Research Station of APRI, Agriculture Research Centre, Ministry of Agriculture and has been stabilized over 10 years.

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to spiroketosis and a neural type of leukosis.
Specific reproductive characteristic: A fertility of more than 95% is reported for these birds.
Special characteristic of product: Good shell thickness and high percentage of yolk/albumin are reported for this breed.
Color comments: multi coloured: white or red ear lobes, dark brown eye-rings, brown eyes, the male has white feathers in the neck, saddle, hackle, back and wings while abdomen and breast are grey, the tail has black feathers, the female has pencilled tail feathers
Description of origin: This breed is found in Fayoum Province since earlier time. It might derive from the Mohammed regime or from the Napoleonic occupation. It has been introduced in other countries: USA, Pakistan, Sudan, Saudi Arabia, UK and the Arabian Gulf.

Other special qualities: Chick sexing is possible for this breed.
Color comments: comment: resembles the barred plymouth rock, the plumage is greyish-white, each feather is crossed by dark and light bars which are nearly equal in width for the male, while in the female the dark bars are wider, red ear lobes
Description of origin: This is a cross between the White Plymouth Rock (WPR) and Dokki4 and has been developed at Gimmizah Poultry Research Station of APRI, Ministry of Agriculture. It is named after Gimmizah village of Gharbia Province in Delta and has been stabilized over 10 years.

Color comments: comment: it has a columbian pattern, but the tail is barred, each feather is crossed by light and red bars which are nearly equal in width for the males, while in the females the red bars are wider
Description of origin: This is a cross between the RIR and Dokki4 (Dokki4 is a cross between Fayoumi and Barred Plymouth Rock) and has been developed at Montazah Poultry Research Station of Apri, Ministry of Agriculture. This composite has been stabilized over 10 years.

Color comments: comment: plumage ranges from light to rich buff with brown feathers on the neck, hackle and wings, tail feathers are white and the ear lobes are red
Description of origin: It was developed by Montazah Poultry Research Station of Apri: named after a district near Alexandria and is a cross between Alex male and Dokki 4 female. It has stabilized for over 10 years. The Alexandria strain is a 4-way cross of Plymouth, RIR, WL and Fayoumi.

Other special qualities: Chick sexing is possible for this breed.
Color comments: comment: resembles the Plymouth Rock in plumage
Description of origin: It is a cross between the White Leghorn and Dokki4. It is named after the Matrouh Governorate and was developed at Borg El-Arab Poultry Research Station of Apri, Ministry of Agriculture. The composite has been stabilized over 10 years

Color comments: comment: it resembles the light sussex in plumage colour
Description of origin: This breed has been developed by crossing RIR and Dokki4 and at Montazah Poultry Research Station of Apri, Ministry of Agriculture. It has been stabilized over 10 years.

Specific reproductive characteristic: A fertility of more than 95% is reported for these birds.
Color comments: comment: adults are golden and light brown with some black in the hackle and tail, the beak is yellow and the ear lobes are red
Description of origin: It could be the result of natural crossing between unknown indigenous breed chickens and some foreign breeds since earlier time.

Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals breed all year round. The following data (birth rates) were given: Singles 25%; Twins 46%; Triplets 25%: Quadruplets 4%.
Color comments:
uni coloured: black, grey, red, white
multi coloured: black, grey, red, white
Horn shape size and comments: horns curve backwards with a downwards inclination
Location within country: The breed originated in the Nile Valley and Delta region and is now distributed in Lower Egypt.
Performance data reference: F54-134 FAO Breed Survey Ahmed I.A. and Tantawy A.O. (1960) Emp. J. Exp. Agric., 28; 74-83. Ashmawy G.M. (1982) Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Goat Producgtion and Diseases. Arizona, USA. El-Serafy et al (1981) Agric. Res. Rev. 58: 137-153, Ministry of Agriculture, Egypt. Fares A.H. (1964) M.Sc. Thesis, Alexandria University, Egypt; Galal E.S.E. (1987) AGA/FAO PaFo. 54.

Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals breed all year round.
Color comments: uni coloured: black often white spots on head and legs
Horn shape size and comments: horns resemble those of the Baladi breed
Description of origin: This breed similar to Libyan and originated in the north-western coastal desert of Egypt and is the smallest among the indigenous breeds (Baladi, Nubi).
Location within country: Matrough Governorate, North-western Egypt. Lower Egypt and delta, newly reclaimed & desert.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Aboul Naga A.; El-Shobokshy A.S. (1981) In: Nutrition and Systems of Goat feeding, International Symposium, France 12-15 May 1981 723-728. Aboul-Naga A.;& Heider A.T. (1984) International Conference on Milk Production in Developing Countries, Edinburgh, UK. Galal E.S.E. (1987) AGA/FAO PaFo. 54.
Managment conditions performance measure: Data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 12 months at night only and fed on grazing and fodder.
Comments managment conditions: Flock/herd size is between 50 and 200 but it can reach thousands in a few occasions. Lambs are fattened on barley and concentrate supplement bought in the valley.
Additional performance parameters:
- weaning weight (4 months): 11 kgs;
- yearling weight: 18 kgs;
- preweaning kids: viability 47%;
- milk peak yield: 1.1 kg/day;
- feed efficiency: 6.8 kg TDN/kg gain in weight;
- conception rate: 85%;

Location within country: lower Egypt & delta and newly reclaimed & desert.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Younis et al (1982) 6th Intl. Conf. Anim. & Poult. Prod. Zagazig, 21-23 Sept 1982, Egypt.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed all year round at night only and fed on grazing and concentrates.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is tolerant to high temperatures due to the introduction of some Sudanese Goat to the breed.
Description of origin: some Sudanese Goat influence
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Aboul-Naga A. (1988) Bulletin No. 13 Agri. Ext. Res. Inst., Ministry of Agriculture, Egypt.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, fully housed for 8 months and all the year over night and fed on grazing and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: - weaning weight: kg 8-10;

Color comments: uni coloured: black, also lighter brown
Horn shape size and comments: long horns of different shapes, spiralling outwards and upwards in males
Description of origin: originated from the oases in southern Egypt
Location within country: Oases of southern Egypt, west of the Nile Valley
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Galal E.S.E. (1987) AGA/FAO Paper No. 54
Managment conditions performance measure: Documented information on this breed is scarce. The University of Al-Azhar has purchased a number of these animals for experimental purposes.
Comments managment conditions: These animals are housed all year at night only. These are ""house goats"" and are kept in the house.

Color comments: uni coloured: often light brown and dark spots, also black and spots
Description of origin: from the Riverine Nubian, southern Egypt: Nuba is thought to be a progenitor of the Angola-Nubian goat
Location within country: North-east of the Nile Delta, Upper Egypt (southern Egypt)

(1982) Ph.D. Thesis, Alexandria University, Egypt. Said M.M. (1983) M.Sc. Thesis, Zagazig University, Egypt. Shalash et al (1970) Vet. Med. J. U.A.R. 18, 295-312.

- weaning weight (4 months) 10 kg;

- milk peak yield 1.2 kg/day;
- feed efficiency 6.5 kg TDN/kg gain in weight;
- conception rate 64%;

Description Of Specific Uses: used for leisure.

Color comments: uni coloured: black
Description of origin: cross-breeding was practised for several generations between Baladi (indigenous breed) rabbits and Giant Flander (exotic breed) in stations of Poultry Breeding, Ministry of Agriculture (Badawy, 1975). Heavu does (50% Giant / 50% Baldai) were backcrossed with Giant Flander bucks for several generations. The animals were selected for pure black coloured.
Additional performance parameters: - litter size at weaning (n): 4.5; - age od doe at first kidding (month): 9.0; - days open: 27; - kidding interval: 55 days;

Color comments: uni coloured: red
Description of origin: cross-breeding was practised for several generations between Baladi (indigenous breed) rabbits and Giant Flander (exotic breed) in stations of Poultry Breeding, Ministry of Agriculture (Badawy, 1975). Heavu does (50% Giant / 50% Baldai) were backcrossed with Giant Flander bucks for several generations. The animals were selected for pure red coloured.
Additional performance parameters: - litter size at 21 days (n): 4.7; - litter size at weaning (n): 4.5; - age od doe at first kidding (month): 9.5; - days open: 28; - kidding interval: 56 days;

Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is well adapted to desert conditions.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Additional performance parameters: - litter size at weaning (n): 5.3; - age od doe at first kidding (month): 9.5; - days open: 28; - kidding interval: 61 days;

Other name: Barqi, Bedouin, Dernawi, Libyan, Mariouti, Maryuti, Arab
Adaptability to specific environment: These animals are well adapted to live under desert conditions.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for a long breeding season (300 days) and good mothering abilities.
Special characteristic of product: Milk production of ewes is low.
Other special qualities: The breed is considered the main contributor to livestock population in the Mediterranean area.
Color comments: multi coloured: white, usually brown or black head and legs
Description of origin: Barbary type

Galal E.S.E. (1987) FAO/AGA PaFo. 54. Younis et al (1976) Indian J. Anim. Sci. 46: 636-641. Zahed S.M. (1988) M.Sc. Thesis Al-Azhar University, Egypt.

- kemp 2.4-8.4%;
- twinning rate 2-5%;

- number of lambs weaned 0.7-0.72;

Description of origin: not very distinct, maybe a composite of Ossimi, Rahmani and other breeds
Location within country: Nile Delta, mainly in the eastern part
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Galal, E.S.E. (1987) AGA/FAO Paper No. 54. Younis et al (1982) 6th Intl. Conf. on Animal & Poultry Production, Zagazig 21-23 Sept. 1982, Egypt.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data was collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 2 months at night only and fed on grazing and concentrates.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to variable (versatile) conditions and are generally more adapted to the variable conditions of the valley than other breeds.
Specific reproductive characteristic: A breeding season of 240 days is reported for this breed.

uni coloured: brown
comment: fading with age

Description of origin: This breed originated in northern Syria and northern Turkey and was introduced into Egypt in the 9th century. The original stock is the Red Karman from Turkey.

Performance data reference: F54-121 F66-80 FAO Breed Survey A13 - 59 Aboul-Naga et al (1981) J. Agri. Sci. Cambridge 97: 297-301. Aboul-Naga & Afifi (1980) J. Agri. Sci. Cambridge 95: 365-370. Zahed S.M. (1988) M.Sc. Thesis, Al-azhar University, Egypt.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to hot temperatures.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ewes cycle all year round and a high twining rate is reported for this breed.
Special characteristic of product: The wool is locally processed for rugs and blankets.
Color comments: uni coloured: mostly dark brown, may be cream white or mixed
Description of origin: This is the oldest of the Egyptian breeds found in Upper Egypt.
Location within country: Qena (south of Naga Hammadi), Sohage and Aswan Governorates (southern Egypt)and southern parts of Upper Egypt
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey F54-122 El-Hommosi; Abdel-Hafiz (1976) Assiut J. Agri. Sci. (Egyptian) 7: 187-201. El-Hommosi; Abdel-Hafiz (1977) Assiut Vet. Med J. (Egyptian) 4: 210-210. Galal E.S.E. (1987) AGA/FAO PaFo. 54.

- weaning weight 15-17 kg;
- twinning rate 5%;

Location within country: found mainly in Denkalia and along the southern Red sea coast
Performance data reference: W41-5 Tesfaye Cherinet et al. (?) Livestock breeds/types and improvment programs in Ethiopia.

Color comments:
uni coloured: usually chestnut
multi coloured: also pied
Description of origin: probably a result of recent imports from Arabian Peninsula
Location within country: found mostly in eastern lowlands, north Massawa

Comments managment conditions:
The animals are kept under pastoral conditions.
This type is a dual purpose breed but most farmers keep them for milk.

uni coloured: brown, occasionally white

Performance data reference: F88-64 Goat types of Ethiopia and Eritrea: physical description and management systems (1994)

Color comments: uni coloured: black

uni coloured: white to light brown, occasionally dark brown

uni coloured: usually white, also blond, red

Color comments: uni coloured: black
Description of origin: variety of Ethiopian

Other name: Bidiri North Sudanese, Desert Sudanese, Drashiani, Gash, Kababish, Shanabla, Amale
Color comments: uni coloured: predominantly brown
Description of origin: part of the African Long-Legged Group
Comments managment conditions: The animals are kept under semi-nomadic conditions in Eritrea.

Adaptability to specific environment: They are well adapted to arid environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Animals of this breed are known for their longevity.
Special characteristic of product: The breed is known for its rusticity.
Color comments: uni coloured: dark, light and spotted grey
Description of origin: equus asnus taemoppus influenced genetically by asian onapro

Other name: Ase Balear, Ase Mallorquí, Ase Menorquí, Asno Balear
Additional information: 2005: ""Ase Mallorquí"" and ""Mallorquina"" are the same breed and now the name of this breed is ""Balear""
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its rusticity.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The longevity of this breed is remarkable.
Color comments: uni coloured: black and white-greyish
Description of origin: Mediterranean western branch

Description: Black or dark chesnut animals.
Other special qualities: These are hardy animals.
Color comments: uni coloured: black or dark chesnut
Description of origin: indigenous breed

Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is known for its longevity and sexual prowess.
Other special qualities: This breed is very rustic and used for mule production.
Color comments: multi colour: black, with characteristic shades on the muzzle, around the eyes, on belly and legs
Description of origin: The breed belongs to the species Equus asinus somaliensis or Equus asinus europeus. This breed has contributed to the formation and improvement of several European breeds. It has had a great and decisive influence in the formation of the American Mammoth ass.

Description Of Specific Uses: Packhorse, draught, plough, saddling, recreational activities and tourism.
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is adapted to difficult arid conditions, capable of surviving with scarce food and water and well adapted to volcanic ground.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is very vital and healthy. The animals are known for their longevity.
Other special qualities: Tame animals.
Color comments: uni coloured: variations of grey
Description of origin: Animals from the north western area of Africa that adapted to the Canary Islands.

Description Of Specific Uses: Used in rural tourism, equine assisted therapy, agricultural work.
Additional information comments: Decreasing population.
Adaptability to specific environment: Well adapted to marginal areas and continental climate (cold winters, hot summers).
Specific resistance or tolerance: Hardiness
Specific reproductive characteristic: Fertility poblems and difficult parturition.
Other special qualities: Tame. Hard workers. Used for mule production.
Color comments: Black
Description of origin: Equus asinus europeus.
Comments managment conditions: Milking is a new prospect for this breed. The milk will be used to elaborate natural soaps. The Zamora Council and the Defense Ministery carry out a breeding program for this breed in the region.

Additional information: 2000: The census was conducted in 1998 and covered both varieties. Although there is a small number of effectives, the results obtained from the analysis of genetical markers show that there is no important and significant consanguinity in the population.
Other special qualities: This very rustic breed is known for longevity.
Color comments: uni coloured: black (Black Alberes) or fawn (Fagina Alberes)
Horn shape size and comments: short horns, half-moon shaped
Description of origin: Iberian branch
Location within country: Natural Park of the Albera Massif, Alt Emporda Region
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was measured under semi-extensive conditions.
Comments managment conditions: The animals of this breed are provided with fodder under extreme climatic conditions since the breed is hardy and manages due to its semiferal condition.
Additional performance parameters: Animals of this breed calve every two years and produce just sufficient milk to raise the calf. Because of the low dressing percentage in yearlings, is very frequent the crossbreeding with other breeds raised for meat.

Color comments: uni coloured: brown (resembling the chestnut coat of horses), the colour may bleach and look like a blonde coat
Horn shape size and comments: hooked shaped or low lyre-shaped with black points
Description of origin: From a phylogenetic point of view some authors agree that this breed derive from Bos taurus ibericus or from Bos primigenius. estrepticeros
Location within country: From Sanabria to the lands of Aliste in the Autonomous Community of Castilla-León
Comments managment conditions: Only housed and given fodder under extreme environmental conditions.

Additional information:
1994: 65 pure-bred males have been used on 1071 pure-bred adult females;
1998: population data based on census performed by ASEAMO (Breed Association);
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is very well adapted to the local environment (mountain climate and mountain areas).
Specific reproductive characteristic: Animals of this breed show good maternal behaviour.
Special characteristic of product: Animals of this breed show good meat conversion index under extensive conditions.
Other special qualities: High longevity.
Color comments: uni coloured: red, with chromatic distal intensification (chestnut type)
Horn shape size and comments: hooked shaped horns in males and open hooked shaped horns in females;
Description of origin: indigenous breed thought to descend from the Cantabric branch
Location within country: Concejos de Cangas de Onís, Llanes, Piloña, Peñamellera Baja, Parres and Onís, Asturias
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was measured under intensive conditions.
Comments managment conditions: Under extensive regime; only given fodder when environmental conditions do not permit grazing. The average annual temperature is 9ºC and the annual rainfall oscillating around 1200 to 1300 cc/m2.
Additional performance parameters: The calf has an average weight of 139 kg. at weaning. Average slaughter weight: 354.98 kg.

Additional information:
1994: The total female population is around 99 000 only about 44 000 are considered pure-bred.
1998: source of data: ASEAVA
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is very well adapted to the local mountain areas with annual average temperatures of 9º-11ºC and 1000-1400 cc/m2 rainfall.
Special characteristic of product: Good meat conversion index under semi-extensive conditions.
Other special qualities: This breed has a gene for muscle hypertrophy.
Color comments: uni coloured: red, blond with black mucosa, eyelashes and tail-tip
Horn shape size and comments: lyre-shaped horns
Description of origin: thought to descend from the Cantabric branch

Comments managment conditions: The animals are only provided with fodder when environmental conditions do not allow grazing.
Additional performance parameters:
Slaughter weight (avg): 520 kg;
Weaning weight (avg): 212 kg;

Other name: Vaca Negra, Serrana, De la Tierra, Serrana, Avileña

- weaning weight (avg): 221 kg;
- age at weaning (avg): 193 days;

Additional information: 2000: Census performed by Dr. Antonio Rodero and colleagues through the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine of Cordoba.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to Mediterranean conditions.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to an arid climate with strong sunshine.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is rustic, hardy and docile.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is known for its longevity ( up to 21 years).
Special characteristic of product: The breed is known for its excellent growth, very good meat structure and good muscling.
Other special qualities: The breed is rustic, hardy and docile.
Color comments: uni coloured: blond with pink membranes
Description of origin: indigenous breed, Bos taurus primigenius: Since 1969 when the latest breed standard was established and 1975 when actions were strengthened and the Spanish Ministry for Agriculture, Fishing and Food subrogated the preparation of the Genealogical Book to the National Association of Selected Cattle Breeders dedicated to this breed of cattle (ACRUGA), Rubia Gallega cattle have been mainly selected for meat production. During this time, a phenotypical selection pressure has been applied on strong inheritable characteristics in order to establish a greater format, to increase the growth rate, to a better conversion rate. The result was very satisfactory and the market of pure breed reproducers and industrial reproducers was created. This programme is mainly based on AI. and cow and bull assessment. Each test is made in accordance with the protocol for capacity control and genetic value determination, in relation to Resolution 94/515/EEC.
Additional performance parameters: Animals are slaughtered with 205 days of age. The carcass weight is 210 kg. The meat is very tender. The carcass has a composition of 78.21% meat, 11.37% bones, the remainder consists of fat.

Adaptability to specific environment: Highly rustic and well adapted to areas of elevated pluviometry and humidity. This hardy breed is adapted to the local harsh and cold weather.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Very resistant to different diseaes, especially foot rot.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Females have their first gestation at 16-18 months of age. The breed differences itself from other Spanish sheep breeds because of its seasonal sexual activity, usually from the month of april to september, time when it is mounted. Black face variety has a prolificacy of 1.36% and the white face of 1.27%.
Special characteristic of product: The breed is highly specialized in milk production, with elevated percentages, long lactations and very easy to milk. The milk is destined mostly for cheese production (Idiazábal and Roncal type cheese). The wool is coarse and usually destined for the manufacture of matresses, tapestry and carpets. The offspring are slaughtered for meat at the age of 25-35 days with a live weight of 11-12 kg. This meat is highly appreciated in the market.
Color comments: comment: there are two varieties of the breed: the black face and the white face
Horn shape size and comments: Males: spiral shaped with points heading outwards and to the back
Description of origin: The breed is thought to descend from Ovis Aries Studery.
Managment conditions performance measure: Intensive
Comments managment conditions: Always grazing except for days when climatologic factors such as heavy snow or ice impede this activity.

Other name: Estonian Black and White, Estonian Holstein
Additional information:
Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
The cattle number in Estonia is decreasing for economic reasons, transition to the market economy and loss of the Russian market. The total number of breeding females was stable over the period 1988-91 at about 125 000. In the sperm bank there is semen from 300 bulls which is partly used.
The share of Estonian Holstein has increased from 32 to 73% in 2002.
Additional information comments: The Estonian Black-and-White breed was renamed to Estonian Holstein in 1998.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for their strong constitution.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white pied
Description of origin: composite of Dutch Friesian, East Friesian and Estonian Native Cattle. First called Estonian Black and White, in 1998 the breed was renamed Estonian Holstein.
Import: 1961-1997, <5% from Holstein-Friesian (Netherlands): 1983-1997, <5% from Holstein-Friesian (Germany): 1975-1997, <5% from Holstein (USA): 1987-1997, <5% from Holstein (Canada)
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for seven months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Description Of Specific Uses: longevity, low food consumption per unit of produc.
Additional information:
Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Most of the pure animals were maintained on 3 farms in 1980: Pyarivere state farm and Vakhenurme collective farm in Pyarnu District and Lekhtse collective farm in Paides district.
In 2004, the breed is considered endangered.
Adaptability to specific environment: Resistance to the local hard conditions is reported for this breed.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show high resistance to diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The females are known for calving ease.
Special characteristic of product: Animals of this breed produce milk with high milk fat and protein content.
Other special qualities: This breed is known for its hardiness, longevity as well as very strong legs and hoofs. It has a low food consumption per unit of production and is considered a valuable base for crossing with other breeds. Utilization of feeds and their energy and protein in the experiment with Estonian Native Cattle.

uni coloured: yellow
multi coloured: combinations of red, brown and white: sometimes with white spots
Description of origin: northern European Polled type with West Finnish, Jersey, Swiss and Red Holstein blood
Import: in 1910 from West Finncattle (Finnland): 1965-1997, >20% from West Finncattle (Finland): 1961-1990, >20% from Jersey (Denmark): since 1985, <5% from Swiss (USA): since 1987, 5-20% from Red Holstein (Germany)
Location within country: Pärnumaa, Raplamaa, Saaremaa, Lääne-Virumaa, Läänemaa, Harjumaa
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Comments managment conditions: feeding of adults: mixed
Additional performance parameters: Compared with other Estonian breeds this breed has a high milk fat and protein content.

Additional information:
Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
The breed accounted for over 63% of all cattle in 1980 and for over 33% of all cattle in Estonia in 1998. The overall number of cattle of this breed has been decreasing, especially after the state and collective farms were liquidated. The principal reasons for the decrease are economic, i.e. loss of markets due, especially the Russian one. Improvement of the breed is still on-going by pure-breeding and cross-breeding with Danish Red and Angeln. This breed is principally found in the hilly area of southern Estonia where the agricultural production has decreased most rapidly.
During 40 years the share of this breed has diminished from 68 to 27%.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the local conditions (hilly areas).
Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals are known for good reproduction.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: well adapted to local conditions(hilly areas)

multi coloured: red and white

Import: Some Danish Red, Angeln, Red Holstein and Swedish Red-and-White have been imported to improve this breed.
Location within country: Mainly southern, also central and eastern Estonia and on Estonian islands
