Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was measures on animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 12 months per year and fed on fodder and concentratres.
Comments managment conditions: Animals are often reared in the house for milk production.

Specific reproductive characteristic: This is a very prolific breed.
Special characteristic of product: This breed is producing good quality meat.
Other special qualities: This is a very hardy breed. The animals can remain two days without drinking. There is a certain variation in their size due to the different environment and rearing conditions (see Sahelian).
Color comments: comment: various colours
Description of origin: ecotypes or varieties of Sahelian goat

Other name: Bariolee du Sahel, Chèvre du Sahel, Sahel, Sahelian, West African Longlegged, Fulani
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is highly susceptible to trypanosomiasis and can be reared only in areas not affected by this disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This is a very prolific breed.
Special characteristic of product: This breed is producing good quality meat.
Other special qualities: This is a very hardy breed. The animals can remain two days without drinking. There is a certain variation in their size due to the different environment and rearing conditions (see Moussoro, Arab and Western goat).
Color comments: comment: various colours

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is highly susceptible to trypanosomiasis and can be reared only in areas not affected by this disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This is a very prolific breed.
Special characteristic of product: This breed is producing good quality meat.
Other special qualities: This is a very hardy breed. The animals can remain two days without drinking. There is a certain variation in their size due to the different environment and rearing conditions (see Sahelian).
Color comments: comment: various colours
Description of origin: ecotypes or varieties of Sahelian goat

Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Description of origin: descended from Barb

Color comments: uni coloured: chestnut, grey, bay
Location within country: Found in the south of the country
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey from regional service reports

Other name: Maure, Moor, Moorish, Mouton Maure a Poil Long, Mouton maure à poils ras, NarBlack, Mauritiana
Color comments:
uni coloured: black, brown
multi coloured: white pied
Description of origin: variety of Maure
Location within country: Found in the South and south east of the country
Comments managment conditions: The animals have to travel long distances in search of food and water and only drink once every 48 hours.
Additional performance parameters: There are very few studies on the performance of this breed.

Color comments: multi coloured: white with black head and neck
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Government Livestock Breeding Station

Other name: Foulbe, Fulbe, Peul-Peul, Peulh, Poulfouli, peul, Peuhl
Other special qualities: During the dry season animals are well adapted to a water shortage and have only once in a day access to water.
Color comments:
uni coloured: white
multi coloured: black and white pied
Description of origin: Sahel type

Other name: Maure a Poils Ras, Mouton maure à poils longs, Touabir, Touabire ou Ladoum, White Maure, White Arab
Color comments:
uni coloured: usually white also black or red
multi coloured: sometimes pied
Description of origin: short-haired variety of Maure
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was estimated from animals kept under transhumant conditions and housed for 2 months. They only drank water one time per day. There are no studies done on the breed in Mauritania.

Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to dry tropical environment
Specific resistance or tolerance: Adapted to cowdriosis an dermatophylosis
Color comments: uni coloured: black, grey, red, brown, yellow
Description of origin: From European, African and Indian breeds imported since 1750

Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to tropical climate
Specific reproductive characteristic: Breeding the whole year
Color comments:
uni coloured: black, brown
multi coloured: pied
Description of origin: probably descended from West African Dwarf, European, Indian breeds in 1650

Color comments:
multi coloured: various colours, from brown to white, also pied
comments: occasionally black belted
Description of origin: composite of European, African and Indian breeds, under development since 1650

Description: Off white with pink muzzle. Previously animals of this breed were reported as having brown or ash areas on the white coat.
Additional information: The animals are reported to show resistance to local pests and diseases. Resistance to heat stress is also reported for this breed.
Adaptability to specific environment: Resistance to heat stress is reported for this breed.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to local pests and diseases.
Color comments: Off white with pink muzzle. Previously animals of this breed were reported as having brown or ash areas on the white coat.
Description of origin: The origin of this breed remains a mystery and up to now nobody has been able to trace back with certainty from where these cattle The origin of this breed remains a mystery and up to now nobody has been able to trace back with certainty from where these cattle originate. What everybody seems to agree upon is that this breed has its origin in North Europe and most probably came through France if not from France.
Location within country: Curepipe Livestock Research Station, Stevenson Street, Les Casernes, Curepipe
Performance data reference: Characterization of the Creole Cattle in Mauritius in Proceedings of the Meeting of Agricultural Scientists (2005)- In press
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 12 months per year and fed on a ""cut and carry"" system and supplemented with concentrates.
Comments managment conditions: The fodder available consists mainly of sugarcane tops for about six months from July to December while for the rest of the year it consists mainly of mixed fodder like elephant grass (Pennissetum purpureum), herbe d’argent(Ischaemum aristatum), herbe collier (Coix lacrhyma jobi) etc. On top of the basal diet of fodder the animals receive a concentrate supplement (14-15 % Crude protein) at the rate of 2kg for maintenance purposes and 0.5 kg/litre of milk produced.

Description: Light to dark brown in colour.
Description Of Specific Uses: Animals are shot on the farm and transported to the Central Abattoir for dressing. The meat is marketed through a deer marketing cooperative all year round. There is also the marketing of by-products, e.g hides and antlers.
Horn shape size and comments: Males carry a pair of 3-tined antlers which are shed and recast annually.
Description of origin: Imported from Java by Dutch Governor Van der Stel
Comments managment conditions:
Intensive: the animals are allowed to graze and are supplemented with farm-prepared feeds. Private veterinarians monitor their health status regularly. There are occasional introductions of breeding stock from other farms locally. They usually possess both breeding units and fattening units. There is controlled breeding on these farms. No housing is provided but the animals are kept in paddocks. Usually a set of handling yards with deer crush is available for manipulation of the animals. They also sell live animals to other farms. Stocking rates are high.
Extensive: The animals are allowed solely to graze but there is limited intervention in terms of creation of grazing areas up to a permissible amount of 5% of total land area in case of ranches on state lands. There is a fencing round the perimeter of the ranches. There is close monitoring of the health status by farmers and animals suspected to have problems are shot since there are no facilities for treatment. Breeding: There is no control at all over the breeding of the animals. No housing is provided. Output: Leisure through hunting. Marketing: Animals are shot during the hunting season which lasts from June to September and sold directly to butchers. These farms are found either on private owned land or state owned land leased to companies/ private individuals. They operate at low stocking densities (1 - 3 head/ha). The majority of these farms are grouped into a cooperative. There are some 15,000 ha of private-owned forests and 10,000 ha of leased State forest land under this production system.

Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to be resistant to pests and numerous diseases.
Color comments: multi coloured: red, brown, white, often white with red-brown spots
Horn shape size and comments: short horns

Color comments: uni coloured: white with black head, often black feet
Performance data reference: F88-197 N2-124 FAO Breed Survey Government Livestock Breeding Station
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance was measured on animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 12 months and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can withstand harsh environments and droughts.
Color comments: uni coloured: from white to light brown
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data come partly from a government farm and partly from small farmers.

Description Of Specific Uses: cross breeding of Malawi Zebu with exotic dairy breed was started during the late 1950s.
Color comments: uni coloured: often black or red, maybe dun or yellow
Description of origin: variety of Angoni, formerly split in North and South Malawi Zebu
Comments managment conditions: medium and low input production systems. An average of around 7 Malawi Zebu animals are kept in each herd.

Description Of Specific Uses: The main value of the local Malawi goat lies in their meat
Special characteristic of product: Milk production of the Malawi goat is quite low, they have never been selected for milk production.
Color comments: uni coloured: black, brown, white
Horn shape size and comments: light, short horns
Description of origin: variety of Small East African
Location within country: more common in southern than in northern Malawi
Additional performance parameters: The performance of local Malawi goats is considered to be fair in terms of meat production and poor with regard to milk yields, however information available is sparse.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to locally harsh conditions.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals can breed all year round. Furthermore, a high twinning rate is reported.
Other special qualities: This is a hardy breed.
Color comments: multi coloured: various colours

Description: Buffalo of Borneo
Additional information: Slight drop in population over years because of reduced utility.
Additional information comments: Swamp type;
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to hot, humid tropical climate
Specific resistance or tolerance: Generally tolerate diseases well
Specific reproductive characteristic: Good breeders
Special characteristic of product: Good source of meat.
Other special qualities: These buffalo play an important role in the traditional life of the Sabahan and Sarawakian peoples and are used in special feasts, rituals and dowries.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Horn shape size and comments: horns medium sized, gently curved & swept back
Description of origin: Indigenous breed
Performance data reference: Tudok J. and Lajium P.D. (1991). The potential of buffalo as a beef animal in Sabah. In Proceedings of the Seminar on Livestock Production & Marketing in the 90's. Dept. of Veterinary Services & Animal Industry, Sabah. pp 21-24.
Managment conditions performance measure: Mostly data from Telupid Research & Breeding Center, Sabah;
Comments managment conditions: Performance data was collected from animals kept under field conditions and housed for about 12 hours daily; animals fed forage with little supplementation; water given ad libitum;
Additional performance parameters: 8 month weight 112-198kg; yearling weight 128-204kg; 24 month weight 308kg;

Description: The buffalo of the swamp
Description Of Specific Uses: Good source of beef. Previously used mainly for draught but with the advent of mechanization, this is much decreased. Used as dowries, etc.
Additional information: In more recent years, there has been some interest in crossbreeding of Kerbau-Sawah with exotic breeds such as Italian and Indian buffalo breeds.
Additional information comments: Crossbreeding of Kerbau-Sawah very limited and covering less than one percent of the population. Mostly the Kerbau-Sawah is bred pure.
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is hardy, very well adapted to the tropics and efficiently converts coarse fodder.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Resistant to most tropical diseases but quite susceptible to Haemorrhagic Septicaemia.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Age at first calving of 42 months; Calving interval of 17.6 months.
Special characteristic of product: The breed shows superior beef characteristics.
Other special qualities: Good carcass yield as compared to cattle.
Reference for special qualities: Devendra C. (1984). Nitrogen utilization and the requirements for maintenance of Malaysian swamp buffaloes. MARDI Res. Bull. 12(2). pp. 248-258. Liang J.B., Samiyah M.N. and Nor Ismail M.S. (1987). Behavior of stall-fed buffalo: A factor determining its efficiency of feed utilization. In. proc. 10th. Ann. Conf. Malaysian Society of Animal Production. pp 276-279. Shanmugavelu S . and Wan Zahari M. (2009). Research on buffalo production in Malaysia. Buffalo Propagation Conference. Taiwan Livestock Research Institute. Taiwan, 12 - 18 December, 2009. Shukri H.I.M., Jariah M.N. and Rozali H. (1987). Fattening of swamp buffalo in feedlot. In. proc. 10th. Ann. Conf. Malaysian Society of Animal Production. pp 272-275.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey to greyish black
Horn shape size and comments: horns medium sized, gently curved & swept back
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Management system: back yard or farm yard production, semi - intensive
Performance data reference: Shanmugavelu S . and Wan Zahari M. (2009). Research on buffalo production in Malaysia. Buffalo Propagation Conference. Taiwan Livestock Research Institute. Taiwan, 12 - 18 December, 2009.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under semi-intenisve conditions, fed on total grazing or grazing plus fodder.
Comments managment conditions: Performance data was collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, fed on forages and with supplementation using Palm Kernel Cake or Cassava based diets. Water was provided ad libitum.
Additional performance parameters: Feed intake: 5.3 kg/day; Feed efficiency: 9.0;

Description: Water buffalo from India
Other name: Kerbau Sapi Tenusu, Bubalus bubalis, Riverine Buffalo
Description Of Specific Uses: The Murrah buffalo is predominantly used for milk production. Males and spent females are used for meat production.
Additional information: Murrah buffalo semen imported from Pakistan has been used on the local Malaysian Murrah population.
Additional information comments: There have been recent attempts to increase the Murrah buffalo population by importing stocks from India.
Adaptability to specific environment: Highly adapted to hot, humid, equatorial environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Resistant to tropical diseases and parasites.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Good reproductive performance.
Special characteristic of product: Milk contains very high butterfat (7 percent).
Other special qualities: Some local communities value buffalo meat for special dishes such as "Rendang".
Color comments: uni colour: black coat, with white markings on tip of tail; skin is black;
Horn shape size and comments: short, flat horns horns curling backwards, upwards and inwards in spiral form
Description of origin: This breed originated from the Indian sub-continent. Animals have been brought in by Indian and Pakistani farmers during the early 20th. century.
Import: Murrah buffalo imported form India since 1900.
Location within country: Mainly in North-Western part of Peninsula Malaysia
Performance data reference: Liang J.B. (1987). The reproductive performance of Murrah buffalo in Malaysia. International Symposium on Milk Buffalo Reproduction, Islamabad, Pakistan. 16-20 March 1987. Sivarajasingam S. and Wan Zahari M. (1985). Dairy breeds and their performance in Malaysia. Livestock Technology (Teknologi Ternakan) Vol. 1 No. 2.
Managment conditions performance measure: Medium-input production system
Comments managment conditions: Buffaloes grazed on pasture and given fodder and concentrate feeding
Additional performance parameters: Nil

Description: Selembu is a result of inter-species hybridization between Seladang (Bos gaurus) and local cattle (lembu). The name is derived from the "Se" in Seladang and "lembu" in lembu.
Description Of Specific Uses: Animals resemble the wild Gaur and are a tourist attraction. Spent animals are harvested for their meat.
Additional information: The Selembu is a type of cattle derived from inter-species hybridization between Gaur and normal cattle. All animals are derived from matings between a lone wild Gaur bull and Sahiwal x Friesian cows in a government farm in Padang Hijau, Kluang, Johore.
Additional information comments: Few Selembu specimens exist. They are mostly now kept at the Lenggong Breeding Farm in Perak. The chromosome number 2n=58 or 2n=60.
Adaptability to specific environment: Highly adaptable to the humid, tropical environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Good resistance to cattle diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Reasonable fertility.
Special characteristic of product: Meat can be promoted as hybrid game meat.
Other special qualities: High meat output due to large size of animal.
Reference for special qualities: Nor Azman N. (1989). Performance of Gaur x cattle hybrids. MSc. Thesis. Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Malaysia.
Color comments: Black coat color with brown patches on the forehead and along the midline. Have white stockings.
Horn shape size and comments: Medium sized horns; curled upwards and backwards;
Description of origin: Seladang x cattle composite
Performance data reference: Nor Azman N. (1989). Performance of gaur x cattle hybrids. MSc. Thesis. Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Malaysia.
Managment conditions performance measure: Government livestock station.
Comments managment conditions: Animals were grazed on pasture. Calves housed until weaning. Water provided ad libitum.

Description: Australian Milking Zebu means dairy cattle developed in Australia and having Zebu inheritance (mainly Jersey x Sahiwal/Red Sindhi)
Description Of Specific Uses: Predominantly used for dairy production. Meat is a byproduct.
Additional information: Australian Milking Zebu were imported into Malaysia from Australia for experimental purposes to determine their suitability as a dairy breed for the Malaysian environment. The performance of AMZ was not encouraging and hence the best breeding stock were integrated into the Sahiwal-Friesian breeding program while the poor milkers were culled.
Additional information comments: There are currently no Australian Milking Zebu cattle herds in Malaysia.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to hot tropical environment
Specific resistance or tolerance: Heat tolerance; Tick resistance;
Specific reproductive characteristic: Reasonable fertility.
Special characteristic of product: Good quality milk with high milk fat (4.5%).
Other special qualities: Good temperament.
Reference for special qualities: Hayman R.H. (1974). The development of the Australian Milking Zebu. World Animal Review 11:31-35.
Color comments: Coat in all shades of brown from light tan to almost black, and can have white markings: underside is lighter in color, while hips, head and shoulder tend to be darker;
Horn shape size and comments: Short, lyre-shaped horns
Description of origin: A composite breed using foundation stock Jersey, Sahiwal and Sindhi; originates from Australia.
Import: import since 1978 from Australian Milking Zebu from Australia. Herdbook maintained in Australia by CSIRO (Commonwealth Scientific & Industrial Research Organization) Australia.
Location within country: Peninsula Malaysia - AMZ research program discontinued.
Performance data reference: Sivasupramaniam, G., Clark R.H. and Keling N. (1981). An interim report on milk yield and calving interval of imported Friesian, Jersey and Australian Milking Zebu cattle in Majuternak farms. Proc. 5th. Ann. Conf. Malay. Soc. Anim. Prod., pp. 105-117. Genting Highlands, Malaysia. Sivarajasingam S. and Wan Zahari M. (1985). Breeds of dairy animals and their performance in Malaysia. Livestock Technology (Teknologi Ternakan), Vol. 1 No. 2.
Managment conditions performance measure: Under government livestock farm conditions
Comments managment conditions: Semi-intensive feeding using forage and concentrates (mainly oil palm based).
Additional performance parameters: Quite well adapted to Malaysia but dairy performance inferior to Friesian-based cattle.

Description: Similar to the Bali cattle on the island of Bali in Indonesia
Other name: Balinese, Lembu Bali, Bos banteng, Banteng
Description Of Specific Uses: The meat is reputed to be lean and very tender.
Additional information: A conservation herd is located at the National Veterinary Institute in Kluang, state of Johore. Performance data for animals at the conservation herd captured using the DairyChamp software.
Additional information comments: Felda Farm Products Corporation maintains a herd of about 1,000 head of Bali cattle.
Adaptability to specific environment: They are extremely hardy under the hot and humid equatorial conditions in Malaysia. They can cope well with poor pasture or fodder.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of disease resistance.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is very fertile, possibly due to the long heat period.
Special characteristic of product: Niche market for Bali cattle meat. Meat promoted as special cattle meat.
Other special qualities: In male animals, the fawn coat turns black with maturity. Able to convert low quality feeds.
Color comments: reddish-brown with characteristic white stockings and a whitish rump patch; males turn black with maturity
Horn shape size and comments: thick, tapered horns, curving upwards and outwards
Description of origin: domesticated Banteng
Location within country: Bali cattle are found in small pockets in several parts of Malaysia.
Managment conditions performance measure: Semi-intensive system
Comments managment conditions: Grazing and supplementation with other forages and a little concentrate.
Additional performance parameters: Meat:Bone ratio approximately 5:1, Rib-eye area approximately 75 cm sq.

Adaptability to specific environment: The animals are reported to have a high tolerance to bad climate and tough tropical conditions (wet and hot). They can live on high lands with a slope of 50 to 60 degrees and at altitudes of 1 500 m asl.
Special characteristic of product: These animals produce good, tasty meat and leather of good quality.
Other special qualities: The Burmese Gaur is the third largest animal after the rhino and elephant. It feeds mainly on natural grasses and leaves from trees.
Description of origin: The Gaur is the largest of the Asiatic bovids. Two subspecies are recognised, B. g.gaurus (India, Nepal) and B. g. laosiensis (Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia and West Malaysia).
Comments managment conditions: The animals move in small groups over a large area and so they cause little damage to agriculture and forestry.

Additional information: Individual cows need to be better housed and fed as compared to indigenous cattle breeds.
Additional information comments: Currently, some entrepreneurs are farming Holstein Friesian cattle under environmentally-controlled housing.
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed needs high-input, shaded environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed exhibits less tolerance to tropical diseases and needs to be better managed and fed as compared to indigenous breeds.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Heat stress can depress reproductive performance. Hence heat stress needs to be reduced using better housing.
Special characteristic of product: High milk yield.
Description of origin: Imported mainly from Australia, New Zealand, United States of America (semen) and Canada (Semen).
Import: Since 1970's, live Friesian cattle from Australia. Since 1970's, frozen Holstein semen from Canada. Since 1990's, frozen Holstein semen from the United States.
Location within country: Mainly in states of Melaka, Kedah and Perak.
Performance data reference: Cameons J.K. (1979). Holsteins and holstein crosses. Malayan Agricultural Journal 51:204-216. Sivarajasingam S., Yusof S., Ngah M., Sivasubramaniam G., Abas M. O. and Eusof J. (1982). Proc. 6th Annual Conference of the Malaysian Society of Animal Production, 10-11th August 1982, Genting Highlands, Malaysia.
Managment conditions performance measure: Medium input production system.
Comments managment conditions: Ambient temperature ranged from 24 to 34 degrees C. Relative humidity about 80-85%. Animals grazed on pasture. Concentrate feeding before milking under sheds. Good SPS management.
Additional performance parameters: Nil.

Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is very well adapted to the Malaysian environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of disease resistance.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed shows a high fertility.
Color comments:
uni coloured: usually red or reddish-dun
multi coloured: red, brown
Description of origin: indigenous breed cattle. Descended from Thai.
Location within country: northern, eastern and central part of Peninsula Malaysia
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey F41-34 Md. Arief Omar (1982) Heritability estimates of birth weight of Kedah-Kelantan cattle MARDI Res. Bulletin 9(2): 92-99.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from animals kept under research station conditions. They were grazed on pasture at a grazing rate of 2-4 animal units/ha.

Description: Nondescript composite of breeds derived from the Indian continent
Description Of Specific Uses: Mainly use for fresh milk production. Meat is from males and spent females.
Additional information: The population of pure Local Indian Dairy is decreasing due to its very poor milk production compared to Dairy Crossbred cattle.
Additional information comments: Most of the Local Indian Dairy population has been crossbred with temperate breeds using artificial insemination.
Adaptability to specific environment: Very adaptable to the Malaysian (hot-humid) climate and can live on poor quality forages.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of resistance against tick borne and parasitic diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is reasonably fertile and has good mothering abilities.
Special characteristic of product: Very high milk fat (4.5 - 4.8%).
Other special qualities: Animals have poor temperament and poor dairy character.
Reference for special qualities: Rajagobal K.M. (1969). A comparative study of the performance of temperate crossbred and the Local Indian Dairy - type cattle. Kajian Veterinaire, Malaysia-Singapore, 2 (2), 76-82.
Color comments: uni coloured or multi coloured: white, grey, brown or a mixture of these
Horn shape size and comments: Animals have horns with pointed tips, usually curved outwards and upwards
Description of origin: The LID breed is of mixed ancestry. Indian migrants brought Hallikar, Ongole and Kankrej from South India during the early part of the 20th century. The random intercrossing of these breeds has resulted in the LID breed.
Import: Mixture of zebu breeds imported from Southern India since 1880.
Location within country: LID cattle are found mainly in the western part of Peninsula Malaysia.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Sivarajasingam S., Mukherjee T.K. (1975) Heritability estimates of milk yield and birth weight in tropical dairy cattle breeds in Malaysia. Trop. Agric. (Trinidad) 52: 223-228. Sivarajasingam S., Mukherjee T.K., Djafar I. (1974) The genetic performance of Local Indian Dairy cattle and its crossbreds. SABRAO J. 6: 39-45.
Managment conditions performance measure: LID cattle are normally grazed in tree crop plantations during the day. At night they are mostly kept in stalls. They are milked twice, once in the morning and once in the evening.
Comments managment conditions: LID cattle are normally grazed in tree crop plantations. They are stall-fed at night. Feed supplementation is minimal.
Additional performance parameters: Average Services Per Conception (on AI) = 2.1

Description: Synthetic dairy-beef breed derived from superior Holstein and Zebu inheritance
Description Of Specific Uses: Bred for economic production. Diet composed largely of local feedstuff.
Adaptability to specific environment: The population is bred for its adaptability to hot and humid environment and tropical based feed stuffs.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Mafriwal are raised on government farms under strictest disease control.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The reproductive performance is 20% higher than 75% Holstein cross-breds but 5% less than the F1 crosses.
Special characteristic of product: The breed has been created for economic milk and beef production in the tropics.
Other special qualities: The breed is adapted to be milked by machine.
Color comments: comments: most animals are black or black and white.
Horn shape size and comments: curled upwards
Description of origin: Mafriwal are a composite of 62.5% Holstein (North America) and 37.5% Zebu. The Zebu component is mainly composed of improved Kenyan Sahiwal or Brazilian Gir. The Minister of Agriculture of Malaysia declared Mafriwal a breed on 30 August 1997.
Location within country: Mafriwal cattle are located in three Departments of Veterinary Service Farms in the state of Johore. These government farms are the Institute Haiwan, Air Hitam and Padang Hijau.
Management system: back yard or farm yard production, intensive, semi - intensive
Performance data reference: CHEAH P.F. and KUMAR R.A. (1984). Preliminary observations on the performance of Sahiwal x Bos taurus dairy cattle. Malaysian Veterinary Journal 16(1): 1-7.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were obtained from animals kept under semi-intensive conditions. The animals have been grazing and received additional concentrate feeding (approx. 3 kg/day).
Comments managment conditions: The cows are grazing 18-20 hours per day on pasture and brought in for milking in the early morning and late afternoon. Fodder and concentrate are given only during milking.
Additional performance parameters: Good adaptability to tropical environment.

Description: Brazilian import. Name appears to indicate origin from the Nellore district of Andhra Pradesh in India.
Description Of Specific Uses: Mainly used as a meat breed. In integration projects (cattle in oil palm plantations), the Nelore is often used as as sire breed. It is also used in crossbreeding due to its adaptability to the tropical environment.
Additional information: Imported for meat production and tropical adaptability.
Additional information comments: Nucleus herd had 1,237 head of purebred Nelore cattle in year 2008.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to hot and humid tropical climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Good tolerance to ticks and tropical diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Satisfactory reproductive performance.
Special characteristic of product: Meat of reasonable quality.
Other special qualities: Highly adaptable to equatorial environment.
Color comments: uni color: white, gray
Horn shape size and comments: Short horns, growing outwards and inwards.
Description of origin: imported; exotic
Location within country: Nucleus herd at the Ulu Lepar Federal Livestock Center in Pahang state. Found in tree-crop integration areas in Malaysia.
Managment conditions performance measure: Medium input production system
Comments managment conditions: Grazing on pasture with a little supplementation using concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: On feedlot able to grow in excess of 700 g/day.

Description: Originating from India/Pakistan - large numbers in Central and Southern areas of Pakistan, and in Punjab/Bihar/Uttar Pradesh in India.
Other name: Montgomery, Lola, Multani, Teli, Lambi Bar
Description Of Specific Uses: Sahiwal mainly a milch breed. When no more useful for milk production, animals are slaughtered for meat production.
Additional information: No pure Sahiwal herd exists.
Additional information comments: In the 1950's and 1960's, the Sahiwal was used in crossbreeding with local breeds. Subsequently it was used as a foundation breed in the development of the Mafriwal.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to tropical environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tick borne diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Satisfactory breeder.
Special characteristic of product: This is an excellent zebu dairy breed.
Other special qualities: Excellent in crossbreeding with temperate breeds such as the Holstein, to produce a tropically well-adapted yet high producing dairy animal.
Reference for special qualities: CHEAH P.F. and KUMAR R.A. (1984). Preliminary observations on the performance of Sahiwal x Bos taurus dairy cattle. Malaysian Veterinary Journal 16(1): 1-7.
Color comments: Red or light red in color. Some animals with patches of white.
Horn shape size and comments: Short, thick and blunt, curving upwards, forwards and inwards.
Description of origin: Imported from Pakistan and India in 1900 - 1930: to date no pure-bred animals exist; Semen imported from Kenya - Kenyan Sahiwal in mid 1980's.
Import: Imported since 1900 from Sahiwal breed of Pakistan and India. Imported in 2 shipments from 1985 (approximately) from Sahiwal breed of Kenya.
Location within country: Used as a foundation breed in the development of the Malaysian Friesian Sahiwal (Mafriwal) cattle breed. Nucleus herd of Mafriwal in Kluang, Johore. Other Mafriwal animals distributed throughout Peninsular Malaysia.
Performance data reference: N2-56 N3-60 F66-49 FAO Breed Survey
Managment conditions performance measure: Medium input production system.
Comments managment conditions: Grazing with a little concentrate feeding.

Description: Belongs to the family Bovidae in the order Artiodactyla.
Other name: Bos gaurus hubackii, Malayan Gaur, Malayan Bison
Description Of Specific Uses: Seladang is considered wildlife and has great touristic potential due to its large size and beauty.
Additional information: The lifespan of the gaur in captivity ranges between 17 - 19 years.
Additional information comments: The reintroduction of gaur into the wild by the Department of Wildlife and National Parks Malaysia follows the Guidelines for Reintroductions prepared by Species Survival Commission of the IUCN. The primary objective of this reintroduction is to re-establish, enhance and increase the long-term survival of a viable, self sustaining gaur population in the wild.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of disease resistance.
Color comments: Dark brown coat.
Horn shape size and comments: Medium sized curved horns. Horns curved upwards and backwards.
Description of origin: Bos (Bibos) gaurus hubbacki (Lydekker), variety of Gaur
Location within country: Mainly in primary forest of Malay Peninsula
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Momin Khan M.K. (1977) The future of Seladang. Nature Malaysia 2; 22-27. Momin Khan M.K. (1973) Studies on the Seledang (Bos gaurus) in the State of Perak. Malaysian Nature Journal 26; 163-167.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were measured on animals kept under stationary conditions, housed and fed on fodder (in captivity).
Comments managment conditions: The animals raised in captivity are kept confined to an intensive management system and are given cut fodder.
Additional performance parameters: When Seladang males are mated with female cattle (Bos taurus x Bos indicus crosses), the offspring have massive musculature in the forequarters. Hybrid bulls weigh 600 - 1 000 kg and are 1.4 to 1.7 m tall. Hybrid cows are slightly shorter and about 200 - 300 kg lighter as compared to their male sibs.

Description: Ayam Kampong means village chicken.
Other name: Gallus domesticus, Native Chicken of Malaysia
Description Of Specific Uses: Niche market for village chicken - supposedly for better taste as compared to commercial chickens.
Adaptability to specific environment: These chicken are highly adapted to hot and humid climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is reported to be resistant against Coccidiosis, IBD and Marek's disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is reported to be highly prolific.
Special characteristic of product: The meat is appreciated for its good flavour.
Color comments: A common variety is the black-red kampong chicken which has mainly black and red or reddish-brown plumage. The tail feathers of the male are glossy black. The hackle, saddle, back and wing bow are a of rich red colour, while the remaining plumage is black or green-black. The female plumage is a blending of red-brown and black. The comb can be rose, pea, walnut or buttercup. Wattles are red in color and are of the double type. Ear lobes are red or a blending of red and white. The shank may be black, white or yellow in color.
Description of origin: There are three varieties: the black-red kampong chicken, the red kampong chicken and the less common naked-neck kampong chicken.
Performance data reference: Syed Hussein Syed Abdullah (2008). Personal communication.
Managment conditions performance measure: Under open-house litter system; given commercial feed suited to Ayam Kampong;
Comments managment conditions: Performance measured at a government poultry center.
Additional performance parameters: market age 14-16 weeks; market weight 1.0-1.5 kg; market price RM9.00 per kg; FCR 4-4.5; total eggs 100 per year; mortality 4.8%;

Other name: Cervus unicolor brookei, Cervus unicolor equinus
Additional information comments: Hunting activities and the clearing of forests for development purposes have been the main threats to the conservation of the Sambar deer in the wild. The exploitation of this deer through commercial farming has provided an avenue for conserving and preserving live animals in various localities within Malaysia.
Adaptability to specific environment: Sambar deer are well adapted to a hot and humid environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is reported to be resistant against ticks and other parasitic diseases such as Haemonchus. The animals are however noted to be susceptible to Meliodiosis.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed shows a good fertility.
Special characteristic of product: This breed produces a large carcass with a quality venison. Velvet may be harvested and sold at high prices.
Color comments:
uni coloured: light to dark brown
comment: new born animals have a bright strip on the underside and have several white spots on the flanks which disappear when the animals achieve the age of 5-6 months. Sambar have a yellowish tinge under the chin, inside the limbs, between the buttocks and underneath the tail.
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Location within country: Cervus unicolor equinus is found in Peninsula Malaysia. Cervus unicolor brookei is found in East Malaysia.
Comments managment conditions: Animals are grazed in commercial farms/parks.

Description of origin: imported from United Kingdom
Additional performance parameters:
- egg weight: 75g;
- incubation period: 28 days;

Description of origin: originated from China; imported from France and United Kingdom
Additional performance parameters:
- egg weight: 80g;
- broiler weight with 53 days: male;
3.5 kg;
female: 3.3 kg;

Adaptability to specific environment: Well adapted. Also found in the wild.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Known to be tolerant to various bird diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Highly prolific.
Special characteristic of product: Large carcass.
Description of origin: indigenous breed variety
Comments managment conditions: Usually kept in ponds. Also found in the wild.

Description: Goat breed originating from the Alps.
Description Of Specific Uses: Predominantly a dairy goat (producing milk). Meat and skins are secondary products.
Additional information: Animals were imported for evaluation under Malaysian conditions.
Additional information comments: Population is the smallest for temperate dairy goat breeds found in Malaysia.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to the cold Alps region of Europe; may not be very adaptable in the tropics.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Moderate resistance to diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Moderate reproductive performance.
Special characteristic of product: Valued for reasonably high milk production, and then for its meat.
Other special qualities: None.
Reference for special qualities: Devendra C. and McLeroy G.B. (1982). Goat and sheep production in the tropics. Longman. 271pp. ISBN 0-582-60935-6.
Color comments: Color from black, tan and white with considerable variation;
Horn shape size and comments: Animals could be horned or polled. When present, horns are scimitar shaped.
Description of origin: imported, exotic, recently introduced breed; originated from the French and Swiss Alps region.
Location within country: Small pockets in Peninsula and East Malaysia
Performance data reference: Devendra C. and McLeroy G.B. (1982). Goat and sheep production in the tropics. Longman. 271pp. ISBN 0-582-60935-6.
Managment conditions performance measure: On farm
Comments managment conditions: Semi-intensive management system.
Additional performance parameters: Gestation period of about 150 days.

Description: Breed developed in Great Britain of native stock and goats from India, the Middle East and North Africa, hence the name Anglo (a prefix to indicate a relation to the Angles, England) and Nubian (of a region along the Nile).
Description Of Specific Uses: Has been called the "Jersey" of goat breeds due to it producing milk with high butterfat content (4 - 5%). A dual-purpose milk-meat breed.
Additional information: A recently introduced breed which is often used as a sire line in crossbreeding; population is stable with importation to maintain breeding stock;
Additional information comments: Still a popular breed because of its productivity (dairy - meat) and adaptability.
Adaptability to specific environment: Very hardy in the tropical environment due to the tropical blood in its genetic make up;
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to several tropical diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Quite a good breeder.
Special characteristic of product: Milk with high butterfat (4.5%)
Other special qualities: Dual-purpose, milk and meat.
Reference for special qualities: Devendra C. and McLeroy G.B. (1982). Goat and sheep production in the tropics. Longman. 271pp. ISBN 0 582 60935 6.
Color comments: multi-colored: white to black or red or tan or a combination of these;
Horn shape size and comments: When present, horns lie flat over the coat;
Description of origin: imported; exotic recently introduced breed;
Import: Import since 1970 from Anglo-Nubian from Switzerland, Australia, etc.
Location within country: Some farms in Malaysia but particularly used in Malacca and Terengganu states.
Performance data reference: Devendra C. and McLeroy G.B. (1982). Goat and sheep production in the tropics. Longman. 271pp. ISBN 0 582 60935 6.
Managment conditions performance measure: On government farms with fodder and concentrate feeding;
Comments managment conditions: Semi-intensive management system;
Additional performance parameters: Gestation period 153 days; litter size 1.43;

Description: 'Boer' means 'farmer' in the Dutch language. So 'Boer goat' would be translated Farmer's Goat.
Other name: Kambing Boer, Africander, Afrikaner, South African common goat
Description Of Specific Uses: Predominantly raised for meat production.
Additional information: Currently the most popular breed in Malaysia for use as breeder animals or in crossbreeding.
Additional information comments: The population of Boer goats in Malaysia is increasing due to its popularity among farmers.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed can strive on rugged terrain and is very hardy
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is reported to be resistant against several diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is known for its fecundity and used in cross-breeding for fast growth and body size.
Special characteristic of product: Tender meat used in special cuts.
Other special qualities: Claims that meat especially from bucks has less smell
Color comments: uni color: white body with a red head
Horn shape size and comments: short horns, curving gently backwards over neck;
Description of origin: originating from South Africa
Import: import since 2001 from Boer goat from South Africa & Australia
Performance data reference: http://www.mardi.my/ Devendra C. and McLeroy G.B. (1982). Goat and sheep production in the tropics. Longman. ISBN 0-582-60935-6.
Managment conditions performance measure: Livestock farm
Comments managment conditions: Feeding with forage and a little supplementation with concentrates; water given ad libitum;
Additional performance parameters: Weaning weight of males = 20 - 30kg; Weaning weight of females = 15 - 25kg; Mature weight of males = 75 - 95 kg; Mature weight of females = 45 - 65 kg;

Color comments: uni coloured: dark red with black stripe on face and back
Horn shape size and comments: males: long curved horns
Description of origin: composite of German Fawn x local Kambing Kacang

Description: Same name as the Indian "Jamnapari". Means "goat breed beyond the river Jamna".
Description Of Specific Uses: Predominantly utilized for milk, meat and organic fertilizer production.
Additional information: Jamnapari is used in purebred form for milk and meat production. It is used in crossbreeding to produce meat goats.
Additional information comments: Due to governmental intervention measures since 2000 to develop the goat industry, the population of Jamnapari goats has increased tremendously. They are valued particularly for meat, milk and organic fertilizer production
Adaptability to specific environment: quite adapted to hot climate but can be stressed when humidity is high;
Specific resistance or tolerance: tolerance against tropical disease and parasites;
Specific reproductive characteristic: good reproductive performance when satisfactorily managed;
Special characteristic of product: good yield of milk (2 kg/day); reasonable carcass meat yield
Other special qualities: Very suited for semi-intensive production system in Malaysia
Color comments: uni color: white or yellowish tan comment: light brown spots on neck and face, sometimes with patches of black or tan on body
Horn shape size and comments: horns short and scimitar-shaped
Description of origin: imported; exotic
Managment conditions performance measure: Semi-intensive production system
Comments managment conditions: Grazing with fodder and concentrate supplementation
Additional performance parameters: Meat:bone ratio of 3.8:1

Description Of Specific Uses: Predominantly kept for meat. Pelts are side-products. Also kept as a form of savings and security.
Additional information: An indigenous breed of Malaysia.
Additional information comments: Small sized Malaysian breed.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is hardy and well adapted to tropical environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is reported to be resistant to parasitic infections.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for prolificacy.
Special characteristic of product: The meat of this breed is highly demanded and very expensive.
Other special qualities: The meat of males may have stronger odor.
Color comments:
uni coloured: black, brown
multi coloured: black and white pied
Horn shape size and comments: scimitar shaped, curved upwards and backwards
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected from goats on trial kept in sheds with cut fodder and some concentrate feeding.
Comments managment conditions: Animals usually graze during the day. They may be housed at night.
Additional performance parameters: Meat is lean with little intra-muscular fat. Kid mortality can be high.

Description: Kuda means horse; Padi means rice (depicting the small size of the breed).
Adaptability to specific environment: These horses are highly adaptable to tropical environment and able to utilize local grasses and other poor feedstuffs.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to parasitic infections like Strongyle and Haemonchus.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is highly prolific.
Color comments:
uni coloured: bay brown
comment: may have white patches
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Comments managment conditions: The horses are grazing free.

Description of origin: originated in South America; imported from France
Additional performance parameters:
- egg weight: 85g;
- incubation period: 35 days;

Description: Black colored ostrich originating from South Africa
Description Of Specific Uses: Mainly for meat production. Skins/hides are valuable. Feathers have a subsidiary use.
Additional information: Ostriches were imported for commercial production of meat and other products. The population fluctuates according to the demand for these ostrich products.
Additional information comments: Large farms in Perak, Negeri Sembilan, Sarawak and Sabah.
Adaptability to specific environment: Known to be able to survive from cold (0 degrees centigrade) to hot desert conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Generally quite tolerant to disease; can have problems with ticks and lice which can be vectors for disease; disease concerns include Haemorrhagic enteritis, Green Urine (influenza), avian influenza, Avian pox and Newcastle disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Female lays 40-50 eggs per breeding season.
Special characteristic of product: Dark-red, Low-fat meat (similar to turkey); tasty, economical and ecologically sustainable;
Other special qualities: Life expectancy exceeding 40 years, productive life up to 20 years; can run at speeds up to 70 km/h; can be fed a diet containing oil palm fronds.
Reference for special qualities: E.A. Engku Azahan (2004). Performance of ostriches fed diets incorporated with oil palm frond. J. Trop. Agric. and Fd. Sc. 32(2)(2004): 245–251.
Color comments: Feathers in males mostly black with white primaries and white tail; feathers in females grayish-brown with white primaries and white tail.
Description of origin: Imports from South Africa.
Import: Import since 1993 (?) from Struthio camelus from South Africa.
Location within country: Several states in East and West Malaysia.
Performance data reference: C.O. Leong (2010). Ostrich farming in Malaysia. Infoternak Farm, Sungai Siput, Perak. http://va_malaysia.tripod.com/Ostrich.pdf
Managment conditions performance measure: Commercial farms - intensive system
Comments managment conditions: Ostriches given chopped Napier grass supplemented with concentrate.
Additional performance parameters: Liveweight at slaughter 115kg; egg hatchability 80-90%

Description: The Duroc population is derived from imports of the breed from several countries. Name probably derived from the name of a horse called Duroc.
Additional information: Pork meat quality is highly desirable.
Additional information comments: Breed known for meatiness.
Color comments: unicolor: red, brown;
Description of origin: imported; exotic
Import: Imported from North America, Europe, Australia and Taiwan.
Location within country: Mainly in states of Penang, Perak, Johore and Sarawak.
Managment conditions performance measure: Commercial farms having good housing, feeding and SPS standards.
Comments managment conditions: Large scale commercial sector.
Additional performance parameters: Litter size at birth=9.5; Litter size weaned=8.5; FCR=2.9 units; Slaughter age=5.5months; Slaughter weight=100kg; Carcass lean(%)=60; Fat depth (cm)=1.2; Loin eye area (sq. cm)=40;

Description: Pig found in regions of Sumatra including in areas where the Iban live.
Description Of Specific Uses: The Iban pig is found in the dwelling places of native settlers in Sarawak. They are harvested for their meat.
Additional information: Although the number of Iban pigs has declined in recent decades they are still fairly common.
Additional information comments: The Iban pig is a source of meat for the native people of Sarawak.
Color comments: multi coloured: grey with white feet
Description of origin: indigenous breed, primitive breed.

Description: Descendants of Danish Landrace pig developed in Denmark.
Description Of Specific Uses: A meat breed used in crossbreeding.
Additional information: The breed gene pool is regularly replenished with imports of breeding material from overseas. It has a large litter size. It has good adaptability to the local environment.
Additional information comments: The breeding material is secured from North America, Europe, Australia and Taiwan.
Color comments: unicolor: white; comment: fine hair coat;
Description of origin: imported; exotic
Import: First imports from the United Kingdom. Later imports from North America, Europe, Australia and Taiwan.
Location within country: Found predominantly in states of Penang, Perak, Selangor, Johore and Sarawak.
Managment conditions performance measure: Commercial pig farms.
Comments managment conditions: Performance data was collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed throughout the year and fed on concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: • litter size at birth: 10; • litter size weaned: 9; • FCR: 3.0 units; • slaughter age: 6.0 months; • slaughter weight: 102 kg; • carcass lean: 57%; • fat depth: 1.5cm; • loin eye area: 38 sq. cm;

Description: Breed of imported pig originating in Yorkshire, England.
Description Of Specific Uses: A meat breed used in crossbreeding.
Additional information: Breed gene pool is frequently replenished with imports of breeding stock from overseas. Good mothering ability, large litter size. Heat resistant. Good adaptability. Medium to intensive input production system.
Additional information comments: Breeding stock imported form North America, Europe, Australia and Taiwan.
Color comments: unicolor:white; comment - pink skin;
Description of origin: imported; exotic
Import: import since 1929 from Large White Yorkshire from United Kingdom and several other countries.
Location within country: Predominantly in states of Penang, Perak, Selangor, Johore and Sarawak.
Managment conditions performance measure: Commercial pig farms.
Comments managment conditions: Performance data was collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed throughout the year and fed on concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: • litter size at birth: 10; • litter size at weaning: 9; • FCR: 3.1 units; • slaughter age: 6.1 months; • slaughter weight: 107 kg; • carcass lean: 57%; • fat depth: 1.5 cm; • loin eye area: 36 sq. cm;

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is reported to be hardy, adapted to poorest feed stuff and highly resistant to heat and direct solar radiation.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to be immune against kidney worm and liver fluke.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed shows a good fecundity with two litters per year.
Special characteristic of product: The breed shows a slow growth rate and produces a soft and lardy carcass.
Color comments: multi coloured: black-head and back, white-belly and legs
Description of origin: South China Black (Canton) type and Hainan type imported from China in 1880.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data have been measured under extensive management.
Comments managment conditions: The pigs are scavenging, adapted to the poorest feed stuffs and receive minimal feed supplementation and care.

Description: Quail developed at Institute for Poultry Development
Description Of Specific Uses: Two different lines of IKTA quail developed. Line A specifically developed for quail meat. Line B specifically developed for quail eggs.
Additional information: Japanese quail undergoing selective breeding.
Additional information comments: In demand for niche market.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptable to local tropical environment
Special characteristic of product: Larger carcass weight and egg size
Description of origin: Developed through selective breeding of the Japanese Quail.
Import: Coturnix japonica imported in 1987 from France
Managment conditions performance measure: In special breeding cages. Fed commercially formulated feed.
Comments managment conditions: Open house, force draft ventilation.

Description: A hair sheep breed originating from the island of Barbados and having a black underbelly.
Additional information: Only imports are from the island of Barbados in the 1990's. No other imports since.
Additional information comments: Imported from Barbados by the government of Malaysia.
Color comments: uni coloured: light brown to dark reddish brown with black belly and black spots on face and legs
Horn shape size and comments: The breed is normally hornless (polled).
Description of origin: Originating from Barbados (in the Caribbean), composite of West African hair sheep and an unknown but prolific European wool sheep.
Import: Import since 1992 from Barbados Blackbelly from Island of Barbados.
Location within country: Chaluk Livestock Breeding Center at Chaluk, Terengganu. Other private farms.
Performance data reference: Ernie-Muneerah M.A., Raymond A.K. and Salleh S.I. (2009). Morphological characteristics of Barbados Blackbelly sheep in Malaysia. In Proceedings of the 30th Annual Conference of the Malaysian Society of Animal Production, 2 – 5 June, 2009, Hyatt Regency Hotel, Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, Malaysia. Pp. 67-68.
Managment conditions performance measure: In government run breeding farm.
Comments managment conditions: Semi-intensive farm conditions.
Additional performance parameters: Body length for males 97.5 cm and for females 90.0 cm.

Specific reproductive characteristic: Animals of this breed are fast growing and mature early. They breed all year round, have a high reproductive rate and possess good mothering abilities.
Color comments: uni coloured: white with black coloured head
Description of origin: Originating from South Africa, has been imported for breeding with local sheep for meat production

Adaptability to specific environment: Malin is a hardy breed able to withstand the humid tropical climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant against parasitic infections like Haemonchus.
Other special qualities: There is a lack of feed and a specially balanced diet.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually white, occasionally grey or brown parts, badger face
Horn shape size and comments: Horns well developed in males. Females usually polled.
Description of origin: indigenous breed.
Location within country: north-eastern and central part of Peninsula Malaysia
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data was measured under extensive management.

Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is highly productive and known for its prolificacy. Twinning is common.
Color comments: uni coloured: red or white mainly brownish red
Description of origin: originated from the Caribbean and established in Brazil, imported for cross-breeding for fast growth

Adaptability to specific environment: Animals of this breed are very well adapted to local environments.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is known for its high prolificity and fecundity and good mothering ability.
Special characteristic of product: The animals show a high growth rate (235 gm per day) and can reach slaughter weight in 160 days.
Color comments: uni coloured: white, with black face, ears and legs
Description of origin: originated from United Kingdom: cross-bred for its high growth rate, feed efficiency and body conformation

Specific resistance or tolerance: Heat tolerant, parasite and disease tolerant
Reference for special qualities: DAGRIS 2007. Domestic Animal Genetic Resources Information System (DAGRIS). (eds. J.E.O. Rege, O. Hanotte, Y. Mamo, B. Asrat and T. Dessie). International Livestock Research Institute, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. http://dagris.ilri.cgiar.org
Description of origin: Locally adapted breed. The original cattle and their traditional owners arrived in South Africa about 590-700 AD and migrated along the western side of southern Africa to areas of the Western Cape Province. The breed evolved through gradual genetic selection (initially for traction) from among the acquired local Sanga stock by settled Dutch (Afrikaans) in South Africa in the 18th and 19th centuries. Surviving herds of the Rinderpest plague of 1896-99 and the Boer War of 1899-1902 provided the foundation stock of the modern Africander breed. The herd book was set up in 1907 and the breed association was established in 1912. The breed has since been exported to neighboring countries.

Other name: Afrikaner, Boerbok, South African Common Goat, Africander
Color comments: comment: many colours
Description of origin: composite of Bantu and Nubian, Saanen, Toggenburger and maybe Angora

Locally adapted breed. This breed was developed in the Grootfontein area of South Africa from 1942 onwards, from crosses of Dorset Horn males and Blackhead Persian females. A fixed type was developed through inter-se mating. A breed society was established in 1950 in the Republic of South Africa. The Dorsian (White variety) was affiliated to Dorper in 1964.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected under on station management condition.
Comments managment conditions: Values of daily gain and dressing percentage are averages of both sexes.

Other name: Astrakhan, Bukhara, Karakul'Skaya, Persian Lamb, Persian Lambrakhan, Karakul'
Color comments: Karakul lambs have a dark brown to black coat. This becomes whiter and lighter at maturity, probably as a result of the coarse fibers it contains growing longer and covering the down dark fibers. Colour is generally variable: grey preferred, with black next. Mixed colours are not liked in the pelt trade. Homozygous grey is lethal.
Description of origin: This breed probably originated in the area of Syria, Jordan and Mesopotamia; the breed was widely established about 1200 years ago in Bokhara and China; they were imported into South Africa in 1907 from Germany to where they had first been introduced during the last few years of the 19th century.
Managment conditions performance measure: Performance data were collected under on station management condition.
Comments managment conditions: Minimum, average and maximum value entered for Fleece Weight are averages of ewe and ram.

Other name: AzaouakDamerghou, Azawa, Azawal, Shanun Adar, Tagama, Taureg, Azaouak
Other special qualities: Good walker.
Color comments: uni coloured: red-mahony, blond, dark fawn, white, grey and even black coloured
Horn shape size and comments: short horns
Description of origin: Niger-Mali border.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Pagot (1985) L'Elevage en pays tropicaux. IEMVT (1971) Principal races domestiques de zones tropicales d'Afrique Francophone et de Madagascar.

Description: La race Bororo représente environ 41,55% (RGAC 2007) des effectifs du cheptel national et tire son nom d’une tribu Peulh du Niger. La même race reçoit plusieurs autres appellations. Cette race originaire du Niger est présente au Nigéria, au Benin, au Mali, au Burkina Faso, au Cameroun et en République Centrafricaine.
Other name: Djafoun, Fellata, Gabassae, Gadehe, Hanagamba, Kreda, Mbororo, Ogha, Rahadji, Rahaza, Red Bororo, Red Fulani, Brahaza
Color comments: uni coloured: mahogany, sometimes white
Horn shape size and comments: very long (up to 63 cm) lyre shaped horns
Description of origin: West African Long-lyrehorned Zebu type

Other name: Diali., Djerma, Jali, Jalli, Jalliji, Jeli, Peul Nigerien, Shanun Bayaro, Djeli
Color comments: uni coloured: white, sometimes white with spots
Horn shape size and comments: variable horn shape

Other name: Bokoloji, Chanoun mata, Goudhalé, Sokoto Gudali, Gudali
Horn shape size and comments: Short horns.
Description of origin: indigenous Zebu type
Location within country: South of Maradi and in the districts of Gaya (Department of Dosso), Konni (Department of Tahoua) and Diffa (zone of Bosso).
Managment conditions performance measure: Breeding Station Kirkissoye.

Description: Elle est élevée à la frontière du Nigeria par les Peuhls Katsinawa dans le sud du Département de Maradi
Other name: Baharie, Bare, Borrie, Boudouma, Buduma, Chad, Dongole, Kuburi, White Lake Chad, Kouri
Other special qualities: The animals can stay afloat and swim long distances.
Color comments: uni coloured: light or white, occasionally with spots
Horn shape size and comments: gigantic bulbous horns
Description of origin: Bos taurus longifrons (Longhorn subgroup)
Additional performance parameters: taux de fécondité:67-76%, production laitière:1260 kg pour une durée de lactation de 280 jours, poids vifs moyen: 400-500 kg

Adaptability to specific environment: Extremely heat, cold and drought tolerant.
Other special qualities: Fast runner.
Color comments: multi coloured: cream to light brown coloured or magpie red brown or grey
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Comments managment conditions: Kept by the Tuaregs of Aïr and Kel-Gress pastoralists of Konni, Madoua and Tahoua.

Description: En lien avec la région géographique de l'Azawagh qui s'étalle entre le Nord Niger et le Nord Est Mali
Other name: Dromadaire des Iullemenden, Aïr ou Abzin, Anastaram, Aballe
Color comments: uni coloured: cream to lightbrown
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Comments managment conditions: Primarily kept by Tuareg pastoralists. The Azawak dromedary is also kept by the Haoussa and Peuhl who use it primarily pack/bagage.

Other name: Dromadaire du Manga, Roux de Gouré
Color comments: uni coloured: light brown, russet-red

Description: Ce sont des caprins de grande taille (80 cm) dits ‘’Maure’’ ou ‘’Bouzou’’ dont la robe est extrêmement variable (noir, blanche, fauve, tacheté). Le type bariolé est très représenté au Niger. C'est un animal qui a une bonne prédisposition pour la spéculation en viande et lait. L'adulte peut atteindre un poids de 35 kg. Le poil est ras et fin. Le bouc porte une barbiche et aussi une crinière qui s'étend parfois jusqu'à la croupe. Chez le mâle, le front convexe porte une touffe de poils. C'est un animal qu’on rencontre dans tous les pays du Sahel.
Other name: Arabia, Bariolee du Sahel, Fulani, Touareg, West African Longlegged, Sahel
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is highly susceptible to trypanosomiasis and can be reared only in areas not affected by this disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This is a very prolific breed.
Special characteristic of product: This breed is producing good quality meat.
Other special qualities: This is a very hardy breed. The animals can remain two days without drinking.
Color comments: comment: various colours
uni coloured: white
Horn shape size and comments: Spiral horns in males, horns are absent in females.

Color comments:
uni coloured: white
multi coloured: magpie-black
Horn shape size and comments: Well-developed horns in males.
Description of origin: variety of Fulani

Color comments:
uni coloured: white
comment: black is the original colour of the fleece, but nowadays, as a consequence of inbreeding, one very often finds animals with white fleece
Horn shape size and comments: Spiral shaped horns.
Description of origin: variety of Macina

Color comments: multi coloured: front part is dark brown to black and the posterior part is white coloured
Comments managment conditions: Kept by Oudawa pastoralists.

Color comments: multi coloured: usually pied, white, black, red or brown
Horn shape size and comments: Medium length, thick crescent-shaped horns.

Other name: Azaouak, Azawa, Azawal, Tagama., Taureg, Shanun Adar
Other special qualities: Docile, can be trained for ploughing and carting.
Color comments: Uni coloured: blond to dark fawn, sometimes they are white, brown, pied and black
Horn shape size and comments: short horns
Location within country: Native to Azawak valley north east of Nigeria and distributed along its northern border. Generally, found on the Nigerian border in western Sokoto State. Also occurs in North western Kwara State and dotted along the northern order of Nigeria from Sokoto to eastern Kano.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Pagot (1985) L'Elevage en pays tropicaux. IEMVT (1971) Principal races domestiques de zones tropicales d'Afrique Francophone et de Madagascar.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to a harsh climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments: uni coloured: white, grey and black colours predominate, pied and brown also occur
Horn shape size and comments: short horns
Description of origin: composite of humpless Dwarf Muturu (from southern Nigeria) and Zebu (from northern Nigeria)

Other name: Baharie, Bare, Borrie, Boudouma, Buduma, Chad, Dongole, Kuburi, White Lake Chad, Kouri
Other special qualities: The animals can stay afloat and swim long distances. Kuri cattle are excellent carting animals.
Color comments: uni coloured: light or white, occasionally with spots
Horn shape size and comments: gigantic bulbous horns
Description of origin: Bos taurus longifrons (Longhorn subgroup)
Location within country: Lake Chad Basin of Nigeria, Bornu State.

Other name: Forest Muturu, Nigerian Shorthorn, Pagan, Nigerian Dwarf
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments:
uni coloured: black
comments: generally, black coloured or black and white for those found south of Niger-Benue Rivers and Plateau State, Forest Muturu have a white patch around the muzzle and a tawny line above the vertebral column, in the north, brown, red and tawny colours occur
Horn shape size and comments: Short-horned.
Description of origin: variety of West African Shorthorn: In Nigeria all Shorthorn cattle are called Muturu. There is no distinction between the Dwarf (Forest) and the Savannah types.
Managment conditions performance measure: Available information on the production characteristics of this breed have been compiled and reviewed by the authors from exsisting literature for animals kept under different management conditions.
Additional performance parameters: The animals and their hides are used mainly for ritual sacrifices and cerimonies, particularly funerals. Muturu are, also, commonly kept as pets or, frequently, they are used for prestige or dowry purposes.

Other name: Boyenca, Fouta Jallon, Fouta Longhorn, Futa, Malinke, Mandingo, N'dama Peti, Outa Malinke, Boenca
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can survive under very humid conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Specific reproductive characteristic: They are exceptionally fertile, early maturing.
Other special qualities: The animals are well known for their hardiness.
Color comments:
uni coloured: usually fawn, red or brown, occasionally or black
multi coloured: occasionally pied
Horn shape size and comments: lyre or crescent shaped horns.
Description of origin: West African Small Humpless Longhorn
Location within country: Occur in Southwest (Fashola and Ado-Ekiti) and south east (Adada) of Nigeria.

Other name: Djafoun, Fellata, Gabassae, Gadehe, Hanagamba, Kreda, Mbororo, Ogha, Rahaza, Red Fulani, Brahaza
Color comments: uni coloured: mahogany, sometimes white
Horn shape size and comments: very long (up to 63 cm) lyre shaped horns
Description of origin: West African Long-lyrehorned Zebu type
Location within country: Native to the Arid and Semi Arid regions of Northern Nigeria

Color comments: uni coloured: usually dark red, also black or pied.
Horn shape size and comments: Short horns.
Description of origin: West African Shorthorned Zebu type, similar to Azaouak
Comments managment conditions: The animals encounter the necessity to search for both water and feed during the dry season.
Additional performance parameters: Good dairy animal. Average milk yield 1,212kg over 259 days.

Color comments:
uni colour: cream, light grey or dun
comment: some have darkened patches around the front half of the body
Horn shape size and comments: Horns are very short or effectively absent.
Description of origin: West African Shorthorned Zebu type
Performance data reference: N2-78, 79 FAO Breed Survey Rege J.O.E. et al (1994) Anim. Prod. 51 (1) in press.

Other name: Akou, Foulbe Blanc, White Kano, Yakanaji, Bunaji
Color comments: uni coloured: usually white with black skin and points
Horn shape size and comments: lyre shaped horns, up to 51 cm
Description of origin: West African Lyre-horned Zebu type
Location within country: Northern Nigeria, from Lagos State to Sokoto, Katsina and Kano States. Spread across the Middle Belt.

Description: Most of Nigerian local breeds of chicken derive their names from feather appearance
Description of origin: Originated from jungle fowl of Java and Indonesian Islands
Location within country: All the six geopolitical zones of Nigeria
Additional performance parameters: Start of lay: 25wks. Clutch number: 5. Egg production per year: 180. Average Hen weight: 1.07kg. Average Cock weight; 1.27kg. Egg weight:23-38gm

Other special qualities: The animals are kept (because of their efficient use of water in the desert part of the Sahel zone) for transportation, they thrive even under a minimum water level. The drinking intervals vary from three to five days upwards to ten day intervals.
Additional performance parameters: Dromedaries in Nigeria are very faithful beasts of burden used essentially for personal transportation, to carry loads, draw water, pull ploughs and as cerimonial animals during Salla - Muslim celebrations. They attain sexual maturity at 3 - 6 years in males and sometimes as early as 8 - 12 months in females although matings are usually delayed until mature body size with a productive life of 10 - 20 years. Average milk yield is 2.8 - 10 kg /d in a lactation lenght of in average 12 months.

Color comments:
uni coloured: fawn
multi coloured: pied brown
Description of origin: variety of Sahelian

Color comments: uni coloured: white
Description of origin: Sahelian or intermediates with West African Dwarf

Special characteristic of product: The skin from Maradi goats (Sokoto) is of the highest quality.
Color comments: multi coloured: typically dark red-brown
Horn shape size and comments: short horizontal horns
Description of origin: variety of Nigerian, intermediate between Sahelian and West African Dwarf
Location within country: Sokoto and Kano States, North-western Nigeria

Other name: Cameroon, Djallonke, Grassland, Guinean, Guinean Dwarf, Kirdi, Kosi, Nigerian Dwarf, Pygmy, African
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is highly prolific.
Color comments: multi coloured: various colours

Specific resistance or tolerance: These pigs are maybe partly trypanotolerant and resistant to some other diseases.

uni coloured: black, white
multi coloured: black, white

multi coloured: front half black (or brown), back half white
