Other name: American Heavyweight Silver, American Silver Fox
Additional information: The genetic make-up of the breed has never been divulged. What is known is that Garland was one of America’s earliest breeders of the Checkered Giant breed and kept Champagne D’Argents as well. Crosses in more recent years using Champagne D’Argents with self-colored rabbits have produced reasonably nice examples of a Silver Fox type rabbit. It is likely that Garland used self-colored Checkered Giants for the very large size; Champagne D’Argents for the silvering, fur length, and meat qualities; and perhaps an infusion of American Blue to improve on the meat producing qualities and the blue color. The breed is not recognized in other countries, although in Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom there is a breed called Silver Fox, which is actually the same rabbit breed as the Silver Marten in America.
Additional information comments: The Livestock Conservancy provided text and photos.
Color comments: the black variety is jet black with surface silvering, dark slate under color, and brown eyes; the blue variety is a medium-rich blue with a slate gray under color and bluegray eyes.

Description: In general, I - breed pigs have small body size, entire body is in black, small head and ears, small eye, baggy fat chap, curved and short snout, saggy back, short and small leg, usually steps by its feet, big belly; pregnant sow usually has its baggy belly dragging on the ground.

Adaptability to specific environment: The I pig is characterized by early maturity, high fecundity and adaptation to a frequently flooded, muddy environment and poor, roughage-based diet. I pigs are said to be resistant to parasites. In general, they are considered very robust

In the country-side, farmers mainly use the fodder-concentrate raising system in which vegetable and other agricultural by-products are used to replace concentrates. The pig is often kept in flooded areas where humidity is very high and fodder of poor quality.

Description: The skin and is black, the skin is thick, the hair is long and hard. Head is large, broad, face is slightly broken, forehead is broad and usually has a ridge, snout is slightly long, ears are moderate and slightly forward. Shoulder is broad. Pig's feet are tall, straight, with a coarse ring.
Additional information: The body Strong. the buttocks are wide and the buttock height is usually higher than the shoulders. Pig belly is big, long but not saggy. Pig's feet are tall, straight, with a coarse ring, and can walk on two front fingers. Meo pig is raised in households in some mountainous communes where the Mong people live. The Meo Pig has been domesticated by the Mong people for a long time and living in the cool highlands all year round.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to live under the harsh local conditions of Nghe An province in northern Viet Nam. Description: The Thuoc Nhieu is a medium-sized pig of white colour. It has small upright ears, a medium-length snout, short legs and a long body with slightly swayed back
Additional information: The Thuoc Nhieu can cope with feedstuffs of low nutritional value and harsh keeping conditions

Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is well adapted to the tropical climate of the Mekong River Delta in southern Viet Nam.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Growth rate and reproductive performance are moderate (litter size: 8 to 10 piglets/litter), the lean meat ratio is low and the fat percentage high

Description of origin: In 1900, local Black sows were crossed with Chinese Black boars, the F1 was then crossed with Craonnais boars (a French breed that is now extinct). From 1936, Large White boars were imported to south Vietnam and crossed with the F2 sows. After some decades the Thuoc Nhieu breed had been stabilized.
Location within country: The Thuoc Nhieu was popular in the provinces Tien Giang and Long An and the vicinity of Ho Chi Minh City, and later spread to the provinces Vinh Long, Long An, Dong Nai, Binh Thuan, Can Tho, and Soc Trang
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey, Ministry of agriculture and rural development

Location within country: Highlands from Ibb to beyond Sa'dah and Mareb and Al-Bayda
Comments managment conditions: The does are not milked for about two to three months (until about weaning). Overall, goats are kept in smaller flocks (one to seven animals per flock) than sheep (14.5 animals per flock). Frequency distribution of flock size indicates that in the country as a whole 6% of the flocks comprise of 5-19 goats with only 3% flocks of 50 animals and more. Goats are generally managed, along with sheep, under an extensive system based primarily on grazing on rangelands as well as on stubbles. In the highlands there is no special housing for goat, animals are mostly kept with cattle and sheep in the ground floor of the family dwelling. In the warmer parts of the country the goats are penned in open enclosures adjacent to the family dwelling to discourage theft and predators.

Description: The Barri sheep, also known as Dhamari or Jhrani, is one of Yemeni indigenous breed of sheep. This is the largest sheep breed of the country with fairly deep body and blocky conformation, but relatively small in size compared to the most of the breed in the Near- East. Adult ewes under good management range from 25 to 45 kg body weight and rams from 30 to 55 kg . It is a hair sheep and fat-tailed, the tail sometime reaches below the hock when animals are in good condition. The head has slightly convex profile and with a long muzzle. The typical colour is white with dark fawn along the spinal region, on the top of the head and on the lower legs with semi-pendulous ears. This breed spread in highlands region and throughout the mountain plains of Yemen.
Additional information: The Barri sheep, also known as Thamari or Jhrani, is one of Yemeni indigenous breed of sheep. This is the largest sheep breed of the country with fairly deep body and blocky conformation, but relatively small in size compared to the most of the breed in the Near- East. It is a hair sheep and fat-tailed, the tail sometime reaches below the hock when animals are in good condition. The head has slightly convex profile and with a long muzzle. The typical colour is white with dark fawn along the spinal region, on the tope of the head and on the lower legs with semi-pendulous ears. The potential of the breed was considered to be appropriate for meat production
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is a very suitable animal to express its genetic potential under these environmental conditions
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is good resistance and tolerance of drought and hard environmental. It spread in highlands region and throughout the mountain plains of Yemen
Specific reproductive characteristic: traits of reproductive is very good, the fertility rate is high
Color comments: The typical colour is white with dark fawn along the spinal region,
Managment conditions performance measure: semi intensive system
Comments managment conditions: sheep practices in the highlands are mostly sedentary—herds leave and return to the homesteads on a daily basis. Herding in general is done mostly by old men and children, and herds of different households are sometimes combined for practical reasons. Herders leave home at 9:00 AM with the sheep, goats, and donkeys (for hauling water) Before leaving home the animals are fed sorghum stalks, particularly during the dry season. Grazing is rotated among rangeland, fallow land belonging to the owner of the flock or rain-fed alfalfa fields. The herd will return in late afternoon and are usually supplemented with straw and sometimes alfalfa. Fallow fields consist of crop residues and are covered by weeds and Bermuda grass.

Location within country: Taiz and part of Ibb governorates

Description Of Specific Uses: Meat producing sheep breed
Additional information: The Dorper Sheep was developed in South Africa and was classified by the Government as a “Landrace”. Dorper is a meat producing sheep breed and it has the ability to produce 3 lambs in a 24 month cycle. These lambs will be slaughter ready when they are about 3 to 4 months old. Dorper is known for their outstanding carcass quality and evident of the above it that Dorper has won the National SAMIC carcass competition for the past 35 years in a row
Adaptability to specific environment: Very adaptable and can be farmed in all parts of the country and World
Specific resistance or tolerance: Dorper is not less nor more resistant or tolerant against diseases than any other sheep breed
Specific reproductive characteristic: Dorper is a non-seasonal when it comes to breeding and they are very much capable to produce a lamb every 8 months
Special characteristic of product: Mutton sheep breed with a top quality carcass at a relative early age
Other special qualities: Dorper is known as the sheep breed with the best carcass. Many people refer to Dorper as the “Carcass King” Dorper has won the SAMIC National Carcass competition for 35 years in a row. Dorper is so dominant that sometimes take the first 40 out of 50 places in the SAMIC Carcass competition
Color comments: uni coloured: white with black head, often black feet
Description of origin: originated at Grootfontein: composite of Dorset Horn rams (50%) and Blackhead Persian ewes (50%)
Location within country: Most parts of South Africa, but more concentrated in the Northern Cape Province
Managment conditions performance measure: Veld conditions
Comments managment conditions: Normal rainfall years

Description: The Dohne Merino is a polled sheep with a good meat conformation and high quality fine to medium Merino wool which is a source of additional income.
Description Of Specific Uses: Dohne Merino is a dual sheep breed with excellent mutton production and excellent Merino type fleece of high quality apparel wool.
Additional information: The breed was developed from a crossbreeding experiment between the old German Merino and the South African Merino
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to natural grazing for small stock
Specific resistance or tolerance: Fleece rot, Fly strike, Internal parasites, Drought and high rainfall.
Specific reproductive characteristic: High levels of reproduction more than 3000 triplets (quads etc) registered at the breed society, every year.
Special characteristic of product: High quality lamb Meat  High quality wool MF4 and less than 20 micron
Other special qualities: Easy care sheep breed
Color comments: White but sometimes sun speckles can occur and amber pigment around eyes and genitals
Description of origin: originated at Dohne Research Station: composite of German (Mutton) Merino and South African Merino
Location within country: Dohne Merinos are distributed right across the South African sub-continent except for the Limpopo bushveld areas
Managment conditions performance measure: Good commercial farming conditions (Intensive)
Comments managment conditions: It is required that stud animals are managed at the same level as commercial flocks until final evaluation at 12 months of age
Additional performance parameters: Ewe productivity is measured as total lifetime ewe records to select stud sires - between 8 and 12 lambs per ewe lifetime is the norm

Description Of Specific Uses: Meat producing sheep breed
Additional information: It is a fat-tailed breed with long slender body conformation. It is a hardy and prolific breed, Is reproductively perform well under extensive conditions.
Adaptability to specific environment: Fat-tailed sheep breeds are popular for their ability to survive in harsh arid environs
Specific resistance or tolerance: Breed can tolerate extreme temperatures and moreover, It has outstanding diseases resistance to most African sheep diseases and internal and external parasites.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Namaqua Afrikaner ewes have excellent mothering instincts.
Special characteristic of product: Meat- Namaqua produces a longer, narrower carcass with more fat at the posterior parts and less fat at the anterior parts. Fat tail- The fat tail can weigh as much as 8 to 12 kg. During the winter months, the fat tail is quite in demand to be used with beef. The cubes of fat are firm and used for sausage making. Skins - Namaqua Afrikaner skins are classified as glover skins. This kind of skin is suitable for manufacturing top class leather articles such as lightweight jackets and gloves. The clothing leathers produced from these skins have a fine suede and a very pleasant handle.
Other special qualities: Namaqua Afrikaner ewes are early maturing breed Is able to rear a 90% lamb crop under high temperatures and arid conditions with a precipitation of less than 150 mm p.a
Reference for special qualities: Namaqua Afrikaner ewes can be successfully mated at an early age, as well as throughout the year, and is especially suitable for mutton production under harsh conditions
Color comments: uni coloured: white usually with black or brown head
Description of origin: variety of Africander, descended from Namaqua (variety of Hottentot)
Managment conditions performance measure: Arid to Sub Arid

Description: It is a large dual-purpose sheep with a good conformation, meat properties and high-quality white wool.
Additional information: The SA Mutton Merino (SAMM) is a polled, high potential dual purpose breed with a medium to large frame size and a fleece of pure white wool, free of kemp and coloured fibres. The breed has been used as a sire line in the development of three synthetic South African breeds, namely the Dohné Merino, the Afrino and the Dormer. The Vandor breed also used SA Mutton Merino rams for some time to improve the fecundity and growth of their breed.
Adaptability to specific environment: Semi-arid regions up to high rainfall sour grass veld areas
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed has a high resistance to internal parasites (such as wire-worm) and is less susceptible to disease, particularly Johne’s disease.
Specific reproductive characteristic: SUPER FERTILITY with more lambs (more multiples) and thus a higher income, higher selection intensity and genetic improvement. HIGH MOTHERING ABILITY with a high milk production and therefore achieving better lamb survival to weaning age
Special characteristic of product: Meat – Puts on fat at a later age and can be slaughtered at a heavier live weight. Fat distribution is even over the carcass. Lamb carcasses of 27 kg are still classed as A2 or A3. Wool – Medium to strong white wool, which is over crimped
Other special qualities: Meat: Medium to large lamb carcasses (23-28kg) are produced and contain little to moderate amounts of fat (A2). The even distribution of fat is ideal and the breed’s lamb meat is the benchmark for quality due to its tenderness, juiciness and tastefulness
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Description of origin: The first animals were imported from Germany in 1932.
Location within country: All over the country. The majority of the SA Mutton Merino producers are found in the Free State, Western Cape, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, Northern Cape, Eastern Cape sand North-West provinces.
Managment conditions performance measure: Age at first lambing, average birth weight: these measurements were collected under condition in Elsenburg as the measurements are for Elsenburg SA Mutton Merino flock. Average daily gain: the measurement was taken from ewe and ram lambs finished in a feedlot, from average initial bodyweight of 30.6 kg and average initial age of 101 days. The lambs were fed on average for 15 days.  Average dressing percentage and carcass weight: this was measured from the A2 carcass of ewe and ram lambs finished in a feedlot and slaughtered at a fat scan thickness of 5.2 mm. The carcass weight was measured from the cold carcass
Additional performance parameters: - adjusted 100-day weight: 32 kg (male) and 29 kg (female);

Description: Bantu tribes who moved down the continent and crossed the Zambezi about 700AD took with them their cattle. In the 16TH century, Portuguese explorers reported the presence of cattle in present day Zimbabwe, and the first White settlers found large numbers of an estimated 500,000 cattle in the hands of the local inhabitants. These were distributed along the central plateau, which was a Tsetse fly free zone, and were almost exclusively of the SANGA type. Characteristically, they: - were neck-humped - had a small stature - were rounded in appearance with sloping rumps - had sleek and shiny coats - were fine bone structured - had small, broad and alert heads - had long, thin active tails - had horns in cows which curved outwards and forwards, and were round and fine in cross-section - had horns in bulls which were also rounded but shorter and heavier, curving out and upwards - had horns in oxen which were longer and more widespread - were predominantly black in colour, followed by reds and browns, with yellows and duns being less common - had coat colours were often accompanied by white patches or stipples very broken in outline - frequently had black and red colour mixing giving rise to variations of attractive M’Sundu pattern or more rarely brindle (Nhuru)
Other name: Amanjanja, Makaranga, Ngombe Dza Vakaranga, Shona, Ngombe Dza Maswina
Additional information: • Long lifetime and high productivity • High fertility • Early maturity • Consistent high calving percentage under hash conditions • Excellent mothering ability • Low calving difficulties
Adaptability to specific environment: survive under harsh conditions
Specific resistance or tolerance: heat telerant
Specific reproductive characteristic: high fertility
Other special qualities: This breed is known for a good survivability.
Reference for special qualities: Mrs. S. Moyo; ILCA Report, December 1990. Heads of Matopos Research Station and Mukoholi Experimental Station.

Description: The goat type is found in the eastern and central areas of Zimbabwe.Most of these goats are of the Small East African (SEA) type. The SEA is often termed the Mashona goat with a mature weight of about 25 kg to 30 kg (its small, compact and hardy).

Comments managment conditions: These goats are mainly kept in the smallholder farming sector. Goat production depends mainly on natural grazing with little or no supplementary feeding.

Description: This breed is commonly found in South and Western parts of Zimbabwe and resembles the Tswana goat of Botswana. The Matebele goat is well adapted to the local environment and fertility is high. The Matebele goat is a large ‘meaty’ animal. Height at withers is approximately 70cm in adult males and 64.6cm in mature females whilst males weigh 40-45kg and females 30-45kg. Phenotypically, the goat has short and erect horns when present and the colour ranges from white, brown, black spotted or pied and ears are normally long and lopped with turned up ends although they may be horizontal.
Specific reproductive characteristic: A twinning rate of 62% is reported for this breed.
Reference for special qualities: H.P.R. Taworezvi, C.T. Khombe; Zimbabwe J.Agri.Res. 25 41-49

Color comments: uni coloured: white with black head, often black feet
Description of origin: Exotic sheep breed developed in South Africa.
Managment conditions performance measure: Data on carcass weight were collected from hair type sheep from both sexes under on station management condition.
Comments managment conditions: Commercial sector.
Additional performance parameters: Parturition percentage (%): Avg. 85.2, Min. 61.4, Max. 135 Twinning rate (%): Avg. 11.4, Min. 2, Max. 27 Yearling weight (kg): Male (Avg. 42.4, Min. 37.2, Max. 45), Female (Avg. 35.6, Min. 34.7, Max. 36.5)

Description: fat-tailed with similar features to Masai and Tswana sheep.Sabi sheep are haired with multiplicity of colours from black through all shades of brown to pure white
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to semi-arid, sub-tropical climate.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals are breeding throughout the year. It is stated that the maternal abilities of Sabi sheep are much better than the maternal abilities of South African Mutton Merino.
Reference for special qualities: H.K. Ward; Rhodesia Agricultural Journal, 56, 218-223 (1959). Had, Matopos Research Station I.K. Chifanba (1988) Journal Agric. Sci. Cambridge, 111, 59-65.
Color comments:
uni coloured: brown
multi coloured: black, grey, brown, white
Horn shape size and comments: sometimes horned, selected for polled
Description of origin: indigenous breed
Location within country: Matopos Research Station in southern Zimbabwe, small remnant pockets mainly of sub type may also be found along the Zambesi valley
Managment conditions performance measure: semi extensive production system
Comments managment conditions: The animals can tolerate grass seeds of Heteropogon Contortus.

Description of origin: imported; exotic
Managment conditions performance measure: The value for daily gain is average for both sexes from birth to 150 days. Carcass weight was measured under on sation management condition.
Comments managment conditions: Commercial production of lamb and mutton.

Color comments:
uni coloured: white
multi coloured: black, white
Description of origin: African long-fat-tailed type
Managment conditions performance measure: The value of carcass weight reported here is average for male at 3 pairs of permanent incisors.
Comments managment conditions: The animals are kept on total grazing with bonemeal and salt lick provided for calcium and phosphorus suplementation.

Color comments: uni coloured: usually black, also white or brown
Horn shape size and comments: females are rarely horned
Description of origin: composite of Wiltshire Horn rams and Blackhead Persian ewes
Additional performance parameters: Parece que no se han conducido investigaciiones acerca de Wiltiper.
